titleStmt.title: Diffusion Theory of the Antipodal "Shadow" Mode in Continuous-Outcome, Coherent-Motion Decisions

analytic.title: Diffusion Theory of the Antipodal "Shadow" Mode in Continuous-Outcome, Coherent-Motion Decisions

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Continuous-outcome decisions, in which responses are made on continuous scales, are increasingly used to study perception and memory for stimulus attributes like color, orientation, and motion. This interest has led to the development of models of continuousoutcome decision processes like the circular diffusion model that predict joint distributions of decision outcomes and response times (RT). We use the circular diffusion model and a new spherical generalization of it to model performance in a continuous-outcome version of the random dot motion task. The task is a benchmark test of decision models because it yields bimodal distributions of decision outcomes: In addition to a peak or mode in the true direction of motion, there is a secondary, antipodal, mode at 180 • to the true direction. Models like the circular diffusion model, in which evidence is accumulated by a single process, are thought to be unable to predict bimodality. We compared diffusion models for the continuous motion task in which evidence is accumulated in either a 2D or a 3D representational space. We found that performance was well-described by a spherical (3D) diffusion model in which the drift rate encodes perceived motion direction and strength and the points on the bounding sphere representing the decision criterion are projected onto a 2D circle to make a response. A model with an antipodal component of drift rate and drift-rate variability successfully predicted bimodal distributions of decision outcomes and the joint distributions of decision outcomes and RT for individual participants.

div.p: Continuous-outcome decision tasks, in which responses are made on continuous spatial scales, have come to play an increasingly important role in the study of perceptual and cognitive processes. Historically, the continuous-outcome task has its origins in the method of adjustment of classical psychophysics, in which sensory thresholds were measured by asking observers to adjust the intensity of a test stimulus until it matched that of a standard (Woodworth & Schlosberg, 1954). Continuous-outcome tasks were reintroduced to contemporary psychology during the 1990s by Blake et al. (1997) and Prinzmetal et al. (1998), who used them to study visual working memory for motion and the effects of attention on perceptual variability, respectively. Subsequently, Wilken and Ma (2004) used the continuous-outcome task to investigate the precision of visual working memory (VWM) for color, orientation, and spatial frequency. Since their study, the task has become the method of choice for many VWM researchers (Adam et al.;Bays et al.;Oberauer & Lin, 2017;van den Berg, et al.;Zhang & Luck, 2008) because it provides information about the variability of the cognitive representations that underlie response accuracy. The task has also been used to investigate categorical perception of color and categorical recall of color from short-term and long-term memory (Bae, et al., 2015;Hardman et al. 2017;Persaud & Hemmer, 2016).

In the wake of the increasing use of continuous-outcome tasks in perception and memory has come an interest in understanding them as decision tasks and in developing models that can predict distributions of decision outcomes and response times (RT). To date, there have been two such models: the circular diffusion model of Smith and colleagues (Smith, 2016(Smith, , 2019 and the spatially-continuous diffusion model (SCDM) of Ratcliff (2018). The circular diffusion model represents the decision process as evidence accumulation by a two-dimensional (2D) Wiener, or Brownian motion, diffusion process on the interior of a disk whose bounding circle represents the decision criterion for the task. The SCDM represents the process as evidence accumulation by an infinite array of correlated accumulators, one for each response, which collectively are modeled as a Gaussian random process. The dimensionality of the evidence process in the circular diffusion model is equal to the dimensionality of the stimulus space, which, for isoluminant color and planar orientation and motion, is two dimensional. The dimensionality of the process in the SCDM is equal to the dimensionality of the state vector that determines the number of response alternatives, which is infinite. The relationship between the two models is analogous to the relationship between the two main classes of evidence accumulation models for two-choice decisions: diffusion or random-walk models, on the one hand, and accumulator or counter models, on the other. In diffusion and random walk models (Laming, 1968;Link & Heath, 1975;Ratcliff, 1978) evidence accumulation is represented by a single, signed evidence total that represents the instantaneous difference in the evidence for one response versus the other. In accumulator and counter models (Smith & van Zandt, 2000;Smith & Vickers, 1988;Usher & McClelland, 2001;Vickers, 1979) each alternative is represented by its own evidence total and the response is determined by the first total to reach its criterion. In the circular diffusion model there is, similarly, a single evidence total that represents the evidence in favor of one response versus all of the others, while in the SCDM each alternative is represented by its own total.

In this article, we apply the circular diffusion model and a spherical generalization of it to decisions about coherent motion in the random dot motion (RDM) task. Unlike the circular model, the spherical model assumes that the representational space of the decision process, in which evidence is accumulated, and the response space, in which the decision is expressed, may be of different dimensions. The idea that there may be a difference in dimension of these two spaces has implications for cognitive phenomena like confidence, uncertainty, urgency, and the effects of stimulus intensity, which we discuss subsequently.

In the RDM task, participants are presented with arrays of randomly-moving dots, some proportion of which move coherently in a given direction. The two-choice version of this task is one of the most highly-studied decision tasks in psychology and neuroscience (Dutilh et al., 2019;Palmer, et al., 2005;Shadlen & Newsome, 2001) and a few researchers have also studied n-choice versions of it. Churchland et al. (2008) compared two and four choice versions and van Maanen et al. (2012) compared three, five, and seven choice versions. More recently, some researchers have begun investigating a continuous-outcome version of this task in which the coherent motion may be in any direction (Bae & Luck, 2019). The continuous-outcome version of the task is of theoretical interest because it leads to a striking and unexpected pattern of findings that represents a challenge to the circular diffusion model -namely, it can result in bimodal distributions of decision outcomes. In addition to a peak or mode in the distribution of decision outcomes centered on the true motion direction (0 • ), some observers show a secondary, or "shadow" mode, centered on the opposite (antipodal) direction (180 • ). This implies that observers can accurately perceive the orientation of the optic flow field induced by the motion but sometimes mistake the direction of the flow within the field. A number of researchers (including us) have been informally aware of this feature of the continuous-outcome RDM task for some time, but the first published report of it we are aware of was by Bae and Luck (2019). Figure 1 shows data from Bae and Luck's (2019) study. As shown in the upper panels, the task was an RDM task that used the same paradigm as used by Shadlen and colleagues (Gold & Shadlen, 2003;Roitman & Shadlen, 2002), in which each dot is plotted for one 16.7 ms frame and then replotted three frames later. Each dot has a specified probability of moving in a coherent, as opposed to a random, direction each time it is replotted. Because the coherence of the movement of each dot is determined each time it is replotted it is not possible to extract the direction of motion from the trajectory of individual dots, but only from the ensemble statistics of the display as a whole. In the Bae and Luck study, the probability of coherent motion was either 25.6% or 51.2%. The lower panels show the distributions of response errors for the two conditions. There is a narrow peak, centered on 0 • , whose height varies with coherence, which is flanked, in the low coherence condition, by long, flat tails, with a smaller, secondary mode at 180 • in either case.

The secondary mode is a phenomenon potentially of interest to vision researchers and decision researchers alike. Visually, it implies the existence of motion mechanisms that can identify the orientation of the optic flow field but for which the direction of motion within the field is ambiguous. Decisionally, the secondary mode is a benchmark finding that a successful model of continuous-outcome decisions should be able to explain. Adelson and Bergen (1985), in their influential article on motion-energy models, described a simple mechanism constructed from oriented spatiotemporal filters for which the direction of motion within an optic flow field is ambiguous in precisely the way shown in Figure 1.

The existence of the secondary mode can be viewed as evidence that mechanisms of this kind may underlie the motion percept in the RDM task and we describe such mechanisms and the link with Adelson and Bergen's work in the Discussion. However, our primary focus is on the task as a decision task -specifically, on the claim that tasks producing bimodal distributions of outcomes can provide benchmark tests that allow competing classes of decision models to be distinguished. From a decision-making perspective, the visual mechanisms that give rise to ambiguous motion percepts are most usefully approached by studying them through the lens of the decision processes they drive and this is the perspective we take here.

Cognitive researchers have long understood the value of qualitative tests that allow broad classes of models to be distinguished from one another, either as an adjunct or an alternative to formal model comparison procedures (Oberauer et al., 2018). Ratcliff (2018), in his article on the SCDM, proposed that bimodality is such a qualitative property that might allow the SCDM to be distinguished from models like the circular diffusion model. He reported data from a comparative brightness task using luminance blobs in random noise arrays in which participants moved their eyes, hands, or a computer mouse to the point of maximum brightness in the display, and found bimodal distributions of errors when the displays contained pairs of blobs of similar brightness (e.g., his Figure 5). He argued that this pattern of data represents a theoretical challenge for the circular diffusion model, in which evidence is accumulated by a single process and in which the drift rate, which determines the rate of evidence accumulation, is a vector. The model naturally predicts unimodal distributions of responses as a result. In contrast, in the SCDM, evidence is accumulated by an infinite array of accumulators and the drift rate is a continuous function, which describes the rate of accumulation in every member of the array simultaneously. In displays with pairs of competing stimuli it is natural to assume that the drift rate function in the SCDM is bimodal rather than unimodal, which allows it to predict bimodal response distributions.

Apart from its interest as a perceptual and decision task, Bae and Luck's (2019) results suggest that the continuous-outcome RDM task can serve as a test bed in which to evaluate Ratcliff's (2018) claim. The form of bimodality shown in Figure 1 is more restricted than the one discussed by him, but it recommends itself as a critical instance of the phenomenon for two reasons. First, the secondary mode occurs on the opposite side of the response space to the true motion direction, which leads to joint distributions of decision outcomes and RTs that are particularly challenging to characterize mathematically, as we discuss subsequently. Second, it arises in response to exactly the same motion direction as the one that produced the primary mode. It is therefore most plausibly characterized as reflecting some form of trial-to-trial variability in the mechanisms that determine the drift rate of the evidence accumulation process, which constrains the way in which it should be viewed theoretically and modeled mathematically. Our article should be viewed, in part, as an existence proof of the claim that a diffusion model with a single evidence accumulation process can produce bimodal distributions of outcomes and can account for the entire pattern of RTs and accuracy associated with those outcomes. Our larger contribution is to show that a higher-dimensional generalization of the circular diffusion model can account for a richer and more complex pattern of RT and decision outcome data than has previously been shown empirically or predicted theoretically. We consider the relationship with Ratcliff's results in the Discussion. A partial response to Ratcliff's claims about bimodality was made by Kvam and Turner (2021) and our preferred model is an explicit mathematical formalization of ideas related to those in their article, as we discuss subsequently.

When we first completed a manuscript for this article, little was known about the shadow mode beyond the basic finding in Figure 1 and our own results. Since then, two new studies have investigated the conditions under which it occurs and established its generality and robustness across a variety of experimental manipulations. Bae and Luck (2022) studied it in four experiments in which they varied the coherence and the duration of the stimuli, the contrast polarity, and whether or not participants received feedback. They found antipodal responses with both short (300 ms) and long (1000 ms) presentations and low (25%) and high (50%) coherence, with a higher proportion of them when coherence was low, in agreement with Figure 1. They excluded visual persistence as a determining factor of the effect, as might have been hypothesized from a "motion streaks" account (Geisler, 1999) by comparing dark-on-light to light-on-dark stimulus displays, and also showed the effect was not eliminated by provision of trial-to-trial feedback. They also showed that confidence was higher for responses in the antipodal (±π) direction than in orthogonal (±π/2) directions. Manning et al. (2022) reviewed a collection of studies, including conference presentations and informal reports of experiments carried out with both adult participants and children, which found that participants in the RDM task sometimes report seeing antipodal motion even when the motion is 100% coherent. They remarked that the phenomenon seems to have been observed much more widely than has been reported in the literature.

They also commented that antipodal motion is typically only reported by a subset of participants. This observation agrees with our own findings, using small-N psychophysical tasks (Smith & Little, 2018), that there are substantial individual differences in the magnitude of the shadow mode effect. In what follows, we first present our theoretical framework, in which we summarize the core properties of the circular diffusion model. We then present a spherical generalization of it and describe our experimental results and modeling work. Figure 2 shows the circular diffusion model and some of its key predictions. Evidence accumulation is modeled as a 2D Wiener diffusion process, X t = (X 1 t , X 2 t ) ′ , on the interior of a disk of radius a. In this notation the prime denotes matrix transposition and the superscripts index the coordinates of the process. The growth of X t is characterized by a vector-valued stochastic differential equation,

div.head: The Circular Diffusion Model
div.formula: dX t = µ dt + σ dW t , (1) or in components,   dX 1 t dX 2 t   =   µ 1 µ 2   dt +   σ 0 0 σ     dW 1 t dW 2 t   ,(2)
div.p: where dW t = (dW 1 t , dW 2 t ) ′ is the differential of a two-dimensional Brownian motion, or

Wiener, process. The quantity dW t describes the horizontal and vertical components of the random change in the process X t during a small interval of length dt. The information in the stimulus is represented by a vector-valued drift rate, µ = (µ 1 , µ 2 ) ′ , shown in the figure as an arrow at 45 • (π/4 rad). The rate at which the process diffuses towards the decision boundary is determined by the infinitesimal standard deviation, σ, which is assumed to be the same in the horizontal and vertical directions. The square of the infinitesimal standard deviation, σ 2 , is the diffusion coefficient. In polar coordinates, the drift rate has a length or norm, µ = µ 2 1 + µ 2 2 , and an angle, or direction, θ µ = arctan(µ 2 /µ 1 ). The angle represents the direction in which evidence tends to accumulate, and the norm represents how rapidly it does so. Psychologically, the direction represents the encoded stimulus identity and the norm represents the quality of the encoded representation. of radius a by a 2D Wiener process, X t . The point at which the process hits the bounding circle is the decision outcome and time taken to reach it is the decision time. The drift rate is vector-valued, µ, with norm µ and direction θ µ , here equal to π/4 rad. (b) Predicted decision outcomes for stimuli with drift norm µ = 2.0 and stimulus angles (left to right) of θ µ = (−π/4, 0, π/4) radians. The other model parameters were a = 1.2 and σ 2 = 1.0. The decision outcomes follow a von Mises distribution with precision κ = a µ /σ 2 . (c) Distributions of decision times for selected response angles for the stimuli in (b). (d) Distributions of decision outcomes with normally distributed across-trial variability in drift rates. The mean drift rate was ν = (2.5, 2.5) and the standard deviations, η = (η, η) (most to least peaked), were 0, 2.0 and 3.0. The other parameters were as in (b) and (c). (e) Mean decision times with across-trial variability in drift rates for the model parameters in (d). When there is no across-trial variability in drift rates mean decision times are constant. When there is across-trial variability in drift rates responses in the tails of the distribution of decision outcomes are slowed.
Evidence accumulation begins at the origin at time zero with the onset of the stimulus.

The process then diffuses randomly until it hits a point on the bounding circle, which represents the decision criterion for the task. As in other evidence accumulation models, the decision criterion is assumed to be under the decision maker's control: Larger values of criterion lead to slower, but more accurate, responses. The irregular line in Figure 2 represents the evidence trajectory, or sample path, of the process on one experimental trial.

The hitting point on the boundary is denoted X T and the hitting time is denoted T . (We use uppercase T to distinguish time as a random variable from time as a fixed quantity, t.) The hitting point is the reported decision outcome (where the participant saccades or moves the mouse) and the hitting time is the decision time component of RT. Like the diffusion model for two-choice decisions, RT is assumed to be the sum of the decision time and an independent nondecision time, denoted, following Ratcliff (1978), as T er .
An attractive feature of the circular diffusion model is that it is possible to write explicit expressions for its predicted joint distributions of decision times and decision outcomes.

These predictions provide insights into the properties of the model that would be difficult to arrive at by other means and also simplify the task of fitting it to data. The first and most fundamental property is that the model predicts von Mises distributions of decision outcomes. As shown in Figure 2, the von Mises distribution has a bell-shaped density function, similar to a normal density, but defined on a circular domain rather than on the real line. Most models of continuous-outcome tasks in the VWM and related literatures model distributions of decision outcomes as mixtures of von Mises components, so the fact that the model predicts von Mises distributions is an important point of contact with experimental data. Rather than just providing an empirical characterization of data, however, the von Mises distribution in the circular diffusion model arises as an analytic consequence of its process assumptions.

A second property is that the model gives a decomposition of the von Mises precision parameter into psychologically meaningful components. The spread, or dispersion, of the von Mises distribution is characterized by a precision or concentration parameter κ (loosely, precision is the reciprocal of variance). The precision parameter in the circular diffusion model admits the decomposition (Smith, 2016;Equation 29)

In words, precision is equal to the drift-rate norm multiplied by the decision criterion divided by the diffusion coefficient. Put otherwise, precision is equal to the quality of evidence in the stimulus multiplied by the amount of evidence needed to make a response divided by the noisiness of the evidence accumulation process. This decomposition shows that predicted performance in the circular diffusion model is determined by the same components of processing that determine performance in the diffusion model for two-choice decisions, namely, evidence quality, evidence quantity, and moment-to-moment noise in evidence accumulation (Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010;Ratcliff, 1978;Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008;Smith, 2016;.

A third property is the form of the RT distributions predicted by the model. As shown in Figure 2c, the model predicts unimodal, positively-skewed distributions of RT, like those found in most speeded, two-choice decision tasks (Ratcliff, 2002). The functions shown in Figure 2c are selected joint densities for responses made at different, equally-spaced, points around the response circle. As is apparent from the figure, the functions all have the same shape, and the corresponding conditional densities, obtained by dividing each of the joint densities by the area beneath it, are identical. This means that mean RTs and distributions of RT will be the same for responses made in any direction; in other words, RTs and decision outcomes are independent of each other. This property is a continuous-outcome analogue of the corresponding property of the two-choice Wiener diffusion model (Ratcliff, 1978) and of log-likelihood random-walk models (Bogacz et al., 2006;Laming, 1968Laming, , 1979. When the only source of variability is moment-to-moment noise in the evidence accumulation process, these models predict identical distributions of RTs for correct responses and errors. Figure 2c shows that the same property carries over to the circular diffusion model.

When there is across-trial variability in the drift rate or the decision criterion, the circular diffusion model predicts continuous-outcome analogues of the slow-error and fasterror properties of the two-choice diffusion model. When there is variability in drift rate, the two-choice model predicts errors will be slower than correct responses and when there is variability in the starting point for evidence accumulation the model predicts errors will be faster than correct responses (Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). In the circular diffusion model, when there is across-trial variability in drift rate, the model predicts that accurate responses will be faster than inaccurate responses and when there is variability in the radius of the criterion circle it predicts that accurate responses will be slower than inaccurate responses (Smith, 2016, Figures 8 and 9). Figure 2e shows that the effects of drift-rate variability on mean RT appear as a dish-shaped function in which the fastest responses are the ones made with the smallest angular error.

To characterize the joint distributions of decision outcomes and decision times explicitly, we denote by dP t (θ) the joint probability density that a 2D Wiener diffusion process with drift rate µ hits the bounding circle a at the point X T = (a cos θ, a sin θ) ′ at a random time T . This density is the product of two components, denoted Z T (X) and dP t (a),
The component dP t (a) is the probability density that a 2D, zero-drift process started at the center of the circle at time zero hits a point on its circumference at time t, and takes the form
div.formula: dP t (a) = σ 2 2πa 2 ∞ k=1 j 0,k J 1 (j 0,k ) exp − j 2 0,k σ 2 2a 2 t .(5)
div.p: Equation 5 is obtained from the first-passage time probability density function for the 1D

Euclidean distance, or Bessel, process, which characterizes the Euclidean distance of a zerodrift Wiener process from its starting point (Borodin & Salminen, 1996, p. 297;Hamana & Matsumoto, 2013, Equation 2.7). If the Wiener process starts at the origin then its first-passage time distribution through a circular boundary will be circularly symmetrical and identical, up to a scaling factor of 2π, to that of the 1D Bessel process. The factor of 2π in the denominator of Equation 5 transforms the first-passage time function for the 1D
Bessel process into that of a 2D process whose probability mass around the circumference of the response circle integrates to unity when it is combined with Z T (X) in Equation 4.

In Equation 5, J 1 (x) is a first-order Bessel function of the first kind (Abramowitz & Stegun, 1965, p. 360) and the j 0,k terms are the zeros of a Bessel function of the first kind of order zero, J 0 (x), that is, they are the points at which the function crosses the x-axis (see Smith (2016) for graphs of these functions). The terms J 1 (j 0,k ) in the denominator represent the values of J 1 (x) evaluated at the zeros of J 0 (x). Note that dP t (a) is a function of time only and is independent of the hitting point on the criterion circle. Parametrically, it depends only on the diffusion coefficient, σ 2 , and the radius of the criterion circle, a. The distribution of hitting points on the criterion circle is characterized by the second term, Z T (X), which takes the form
div.formula: Z T (X) = exp 1 σ 2 (µ • X T ) − 1 2σ 2 µ 2 t ,(6)
div.p: where (µ • X T ) = aµ 1 cos θ + aµ 2 sin θ is the dot product of the drift rate vector and the vector of coordinates of hitting points on the boundary. The function Z T (X) factorizes into a product of two exponential terms: one that depends on time and is independent of the hitting point and another that depends on the hitting point and is independent of time.

It is immediate from this factorization that the hitting time is independent of the hitting point and that, in the absence of drift-rate or criterion variability, the model predicts that decision times will be the same for all decision outcomes, as shown in Figure 2c.
The simplest model of drift-rate variability assumes that drift rates follow a bivariate normal distribution with mean ν = (ν 1 , ν 2 ) ′ and covariance matrix η,

in which the standard deviations of the components are η 1 and η 2 and the components are independent of each other. When the components are independent, the hitting-point dependent term, Z T (X), in Equation 4, given by Equation 6, is replaced by a function Z T (X) (Smith & Corbett, 2019), which is most conveniently written in product form because of its length,
div.formula: Z T (X) = 2 i=1 1 (η i /σ) 2 t + 1 exp − ν 2 i 2η 2 i + [X i T (η i /σ) 2 + ν i ] 2 2η 2 i [(η i /σ) 2 t + 1] .(8)
div.p: The overbar notation suggests averaging or marginalization and is intended to imply that the distribution of hitting points is obtained by averaging Equation 6 across a distribution of drift rates. The random variables X i T in Equation 8 are the coordinates of the hitting points on the boundary circle, which are written in the expansion of the dot product term of Equation 6 as X 1 T = a cos θ and X 2 T = a sin θ, respectively, but in Equation 8 they are left in random variable form for the sake of compactness. An analogous expression for the effect of drift rate variability in the two-choice diffusion model was derived by Tuerlinckx (2004). When the mean drift rate vector, ν, aligns with the positive real axis, we say the model is in canonical orientation. Under these circumstances, the components η 1 and η 2 describe the radial and tangential components of drift-rate variability. The radial component describes variability in the encoded stimulus quality and the tangential component describes variability in the encoded stimulus identity. As this representation yields psychologically meaningful parameters, we will always assume our models are in canonical orientation. If the model is not in canonical orientation or if the components of drift rate variability are correlated rather than independent, then Equation 8 is replaced by a more complex expression given by Smith (2019), but it is not needed in this article. precision. These kinds of mixture distributions have been at the heart of the debate in the VWM literature about item-capacity-limited, or "slot," models and resource models of memory. Slot models assume that VWM is limited by the number of items it can hold: If an item is in memory then its properties will be remembered with high precision; otherwise people will guess, resulting in responses that are uniformly distributed around the circle.

div.head: Modeling Distributions of Decision Outcomes
div.p: A two-component, von Mises plus uniform, model is a natural prediction of such models (Zhang & Luck, 2008). Other models, such as the intrusions model of Bays and colleagues (Bays et al., 2009) distributions had heavy, uniform tails. Smith et al. proposed an extension of the circular diffusion model, which they called an encoding failure model, to characterize these distributions. The model assumes that on most trials the identity of the stimulus is encoded accurately, leading to a von Mises error distribution centered on the true stimulus color, but on the remaining trials, encoding fails, leading to a uniform error distribution. They characterized the second process as an encoding failure process rather than a guessing process because, unlike a guessing process, the drift rate on encoding-failure trials was nonzero. A true guessing process would be one in which the decision process is driven by noise alone, which would result in long decision times. Although their data did show slow errors, they were not as slow as predicted by a zero-drift guessing process. The encoding failure model instead assumes that some stimulus information is encoded on every trial, but on encoding failure trials its identity is random, leading to a drift rate with a uniformly distributed polar angle, µ θ . This model, and a second model loosely inspired by Schurgin et al.'s (2020) exponential similarity model, successfully predicted the joint distributions of errors and RT from the task. The second model represented the distribution of µ θ across trials using a Jones-Pewsey distribution (Jones & Pewsey, 2005), which is a leptokurtic distribution that can predict heavier tailed error distributions than the normal distributions of drift rates of Equation 8.

Neither the encoding failure model nor the Jones-Pewsey drift-rate model naturally predict bimodal distributions of decision outcomes like those in Figure 1. Conceptually, the simplest model for bimodality is the one assumed by Bae and Luck (2019), which models the error distribution as a mixture of a pair of antipodally-centered von Mises distributions (the solid lines in Figure 1). Bae and Luck were at pains to stress the ad hoc nature of this model, but it is nevertheless a plausible one. It would be appropriate if, for example, the direction of motion depends on the sign of the difference in the aggregated outputs of two populations of noisy local motion detectors in an opponent-process configuration that signal motion in opposite directions. The circular diffusion counterpart of such a model would be one consisting of a mixture of two antipodal drift rates.

A second, related, possibility, shown in Figures 2d and 2e is that bimodality arises because of drift rate variability. If the component of drift rate variability in the direction of the mean drift rate, ν, is large, then some proportion of drift rates across trials will have the opposite orientation to ν. If that proportion is large, then a secondary mode can result. Although this is a simple way to a obtain secondary mode, a potential limitation of it is that it requires drift rate variability to be large in order to do so. Large drift rate variability leads to a large slow-error effect, which, like the guessing process discussed above, may be greater that found in data. We evaluate the drift-rate variability model later in the article, but emphasize that these alternatives can only be distinguished using RT data and a model that predicts both accuracy and RT.
A third, more intriguing, possibility is that bimodality may arise because the dimensionality of the evidence accumulation space is greater than that of the response space.

That this might be so was first suggested by Smith and Corbett (2019) who used a hyperspherical (4D) diffusion model to model two-choice decisions about visual search for double targets in four-item arrays. They modeled evidence accumulation using a 4D diffusion process and the decision criterion as a 3-sphere in 4D space. The 16 orthants (the higher dimensional counterparts of quadrants and octants) of the 3-sphere were identified with the 16 different decision outcomes for the 4D process, which were then mapped to the response alternatives according to the response rules for the task.

A related idea, in the context of continuous-outcome decisions, was suggested by Kvam and Turner (2021), who proposed that evidence is accumulated in a similarity space whose dimensionality is higher than that of the response space. The dimensionality of the similarity space for any given task can be determined empirically by multidimensional scaling.

They showed that if the distribution of hitting points in similarity space is projected down onto the first two components of the space, which they assumed correspond to the axes of the response circle in a 2D continuous-outcome task, then bimodal distributions of outcomes could be obtained. The intuition behind this property is that points that are close together in similarity space may become widely separated by the action of projecting them down to a lower dimensional response space. Kvam and Turner showed that bimodal distributions could be obtained if evidence accumulation occurs in a 3D space -represented by diffusion on the interior of a 2-sphere (i.e., an ordinary sphere) -and the points on the surface of the sphere are projected onto the response circle to make a decision. They used this idea to characterize the relationship between the circular diffusion model and Ratcliff's SCDM. We implement and evaluate a related idea here. The focus of Kvam and Turner's work was on how stimuli occupying nearby points in similarity space could be mapped to widely-separated locations in the response space, whereas our focus is instead on how stimuli that occupy exactly the same location in similarity space can be mapped to widely-separated locations on different trials through the action of across-trial variability in drift rate. We evaluate the predictions of this model at the level of joint distributions of decision times and decision outcomes. Figure 3a shows a spherical generalization of the circular diffusion model, described by Smith and Corbett (2019), in which evidence accumulation is represented by a 3D Wiener

div.head: A Spherical Generalization of the Circular Diffusion Model
div.formula: process, X t = (X 1 t , X 2 t , X 3 t ) ′
div.p: , on the interior of a sphere of radius a. The drift rate is a three-component vector µ = (µ 1 , µ 2 , µ 3 ) ′ . Evidence accumulation begins at the center of the sphere and continues until the process hits a point on its surface, that is, until 3 i=1 (X i t ) 2 = a. This model can be used to represent continuous-outcome decisions if we assume that hitting points on the surface of the sphere are projected down meridians of equal azimuth to points on the response circle to make a decision.

As discussed by Smith and Corbett (2019), the mathematical characterization of the circular diffusion model of Equations 4 to 6 carries over to higher-dimensional spaces with only minor changes. Characterizing the locus of hitting points on the sphere requires two polar angles, θ and φ, rather than one. The first angle is the azimuth, −π < θ ≤ π, which gives the polar angle of a point in the (X 1 t , X 2 t ) (equatorial) plane containing the response circle. The second angle is the elevation, 0 ≤ φ ≤ π, which gives the height above the equatorial plane. In standard spherical coordinates φ measures the deviation from the north pole. The locus of hitting points on the sphere at a random time T can be written of radius a by a 3D Wiener diffusion process, X t , with drift rate µ = (µ 1 , µ 2 , µ 3 ) ′ . To make a response, the hitting point, X T , on the surface of the sphere at time T is projected down the meridian of constant azimuth (the dashed line), to a point on the response circle, θ, which determines the decision outcome. (b) Mixture of informative and uninformative drift rates, µ and µ , with elevations φ = 0 and φ = π/2 (in reparameterized coordinates) and mixing probability π α . (c) Distributions of decision outcomes and mean decision times for drift rate vectors in the response plane (φ = 0) or elevated above it (φ = 1.0), with or without drift rate variability in the radial direction (η = 1.75 or η = 0). (d) Joint distributions of decision outcomes and decision times for processes with drift rate variability and drift rate vectors in the response plane (top) or elevated above it (bottom).
in terms of spherical coordinates as
div.formula: X 3 T = a cos φ X 2 T = a sin φ sin θ X 1 T = a sin φ cos θ.(9)
div.p: The joint density of decision times and decision outcomes is given by a 3D analogue of Equation 4 in which the components of the dot product, (µ • X T ), in Equation 6 are the spherical coordinates in Equation 9 and in which the zero-drift process is the Bessel (Euclidian distance) process corresponding to the 3D rather than the 2D zero-drift Wiener process. The first-passage time density for this process is given by the time derivative of Equation 2.7 in Hamana and Matsumoto (2013), with ν (a parameter in their notation that determines the dimensionality of the process) set to 1/2,
div.formula: dP t (a) = σ 2 a 2 (2π) ν+1 ∞ k=1 j ν+1 ν,k J ν+1 (j ν,k ) exp − j 2 ν,k σ 2 2a 2 t .(10)
div.p: The denominator of Equation 10 includes an implicit scaling factor of 4π (the surface area of the sphere) that transforms the 1D first-passage time density of the Bessel process into a spherically symmetrical 3D density that integrates to unity. The distribution of hitting points, X T , on the response sphere is given by the von Mises-Fisher distribution (Gatto, 2013;Hillen et al., 2017), which has probability density function
div.formula: f (θ, φ; κ) = κ 4π sinh κ exp κ μ •X T , (11)
div.p: where μ •X T is the dot product of the unit vectorsμ = µ/ µ andX T = X T /a and κ is again given by Equation 3. Jung (2021) showed that the marginal distribution of a von Mises-Fisher distribution projected onto a geodesic (a great circle) of the sphere is not a von Mises distribution but is sufficiently close to be indistinguishable from it numerically.

1 Expressed in terms of ν, the parameter that characterizes the dimensionality, n, of the process, the surface area scaling factor equals 2π ν+1 /Γ(ν + 1) = 4π for ν = 1/2, where n = 2ν + 2 and Γ(•) is the gamma function (D. K. Smith & Vamanamurthy, 1989). This factor does not appear explicitly in Equation 10 because it cancels, in part, with leading terms of the first-passage time density for the Bessel process (Hamana & Matsumoto, 2013, Equation 2.7), which includes a term 1/[2 ν Γ(ν + 1)]. The use of ν to denote the dimensionality of a Bessel process is a standard notation in the stochastic processes literature.

Elsewhere, we use ν to denote the mean of the distribution of drift rates in a diffusion model, which is a standard notation in the cognitive literature. The two usages are unrelated and should not be confused.

So, while the marginal distributions of the spherical diffusion model are not exactly von Mises in form -unlike the circular diffusion model -they approximate it sufficiently well to be plausible alternative models for the distribution of errors in continuous-outcome tasks.

div.head: Properties of the Spherical Diffusion Model
div.p: The extra dimension of the spherical diffusion model endows it with some properties not possessed by the circular diffusion model, although, like the circular model, it remains highly constrained in its predictions. Figure 3 tries to give a sense of these properties.

One property is that the model provides an alternative way to represent encoding failures, as described by . They modeled encoding failures using the circular diffusion model with a uniformly-distributed drift-rate angle, θ µ . Figure 3b shows that another way to represent encoding failures in a spherical model is with a drift rate aligned with the X 3 t axis, which points towards the north (or south) pole. Such a drift rate represents an uninformative stimulus encoding. In the standard spherical coordinates of Equation 9, a vector pointing towards the north pole has angle of φ = 0, but here we use reparameterized coordinates, −π/2 ≤ φ ≤ π/2, in which φ denotes the elevation of the drift-rate vector above (or below) the equatorial plane, as they are more intuitive in this setting. In these coordinates, φ = 0 describes a vector in the equatorial plane and φ = π/2 describes a vector that points towards the north pole. The contours of equal likelihood of the distribution of hitting points for a process with a drift-rate vector aligned with the X 3 t axis will be circular and centered on the north pole. When projected down the meridians of equal azimuth, θ, as shown in Figure 3b, the responses will be uniformly distributed on the response circle. A mixture of the two drift rates will predict peaked high-tailed distributions of errors, like those predicted by the encoding failure model of . However, it does not predict bimodality, which is our primary focus here and, if the two components are of equal magnitude and there is no drift rate variability, then it also predicts that decision outcomes and decision times will be independent of each other.

Figures 3c and 3d show the combined effects of drift rate variability and of varying the elevation of the drift rate vector above the equatorial plane. As in the circular diffusion model, the primary mechanism for predicting bimodality in the spherical model is drift rate variability, either in the form of a single-component drift rate distribution with a single mean vector or a two-component distribution, one component of which has a mean in the antipodal direction. At moderate levels of drift rate variability the spherical model predicts peaked high-tailed distributions of errors and a slow-error pattern of decision times, like the one shown in Figure 2e. At higher levels of drift rate variability the distributions of errors become bimodal and the RTs begin to show a "double-bowed" form, in which the slow-error pattern begins to reverse at the extremes (−π and π rad). This is because the probability mass in the drift-rate distribution is concentrated along the θ = 0 line in the (X 1 t , X 2 t ) equatorial plane. On some trials the sign of the drift rate will be the opposite to its nominal value, leading the process to drift towards the antipodal boundary point. The antipodal component of drift rate allows the model to predict bimodality and also tends to predict faster responses in the antipodal direction, which results in the double-bowing effect. These effects are most evident in the joint distributions of decision outcomes and decision times shown in Figure 3d. The two panels in the figure plot the .1, .3, .5, .7, and .9 quantiles of the distributions of decision times on the y-axis as a function of the decision outcomes on the x-axis. The double-bowed pattern is especially apparent in the .9 quantile functions, which characterize the slowest responses in the joint distribution.

The theoretical interest of the spherical model is that it allows some degree of decoupling or independence between the amount of bimodality and the magnitude of the slow errors and/or double-bowing in the distributions of decision times. The decoupling arises because the elevation of the drift rate vector in the spherical model can vary and controls the relationship between bimodality and slow errors. This contrasts with the circular diffusion model in which the radial component of drift rate variability prescribes a fixed relationship between bimodality and slow errors. Figure 3 contrasts two sets of predictions for the spherical model, one for a drift rate vector with elevation of φ = 0 rad, which lies in the equatorial plane, and another for a drift rate vector with elevation φ = 1 rad (57 deg), which lies above it. For the first set of predictions the drift rate norm was µ = 2.0; for the second it was µ = 3.0, which meant it had a component of µ cos(φ) = 1.63 in the equatorial plane. For both sets of predictions the decision criterion was a = 2.5 with infinitesimal standard deviation of σ = 1.0, and both sets had a component of drift rate variability of η = 2.0 in the radial and the vertical directions. Although the two sets of predictions look similar, the critical difference between them is that the relationship between slow errors and bimodality is reversed. In Figure 3c (top), φ = 0 leads to a small bimodal effect in accuracy and a large slow error effect in RT (Figure 3c (bottom) and Figure 3d). In contrast, φ = 1.0 leads to a larger bimodal effect in accuracy but a smaller slow error effect in RT. This decoupling of the degree of bimodality from the magnitude of the slow error effect turns out to be critical to the model's ability to fit data. As we discuss in the following section, the drift rate norm, which controls the overall speed of responding, can be interpreted as encoding both the information in the stimulus and expressing the decision maker's overall propensity to respond, independent of the criterion setting. Figure 4: Vector field of perceived motion strengths corresponding to µ 1 and µ 2 , the first two components of the drift rate, µ, of the spherical diffusion model. Weak motion strength is associated with short vectors near the center of the circle and strong motion strength with long vectors near its circumference. The norm of the drift rate vector, µ , encodes both the perceived strength of motion and the overall pressure or propensity to respond. The third component of drift rate, µ 3 , decouples the propensity to respond from the information in the stimulus, which is encoded in the projection of the drift rate vector onto the (X 1 t , X 2 t ) plane.

div.head: Cognitive Content of the Third Dimension
div.p: The third dimension of the spherical model endows it with some properties not shared with the circular model, but raises the question of what, if any, psychological meaning can be attached to it. Kvam and Turner (2021) identified the third dimension with a multidimensional scaling representation of similarity space and proposed that evidence is accumulated in this space rather than response space. In the case of the RDM task, however, in which the motion is planar, there is no corresponding identification with the structure of similarity space. Rather, as suggested in the previous section, we view the third dimension as expressing the decision maker's uncertainty about the direction of the motion. (We are using "uncertainty" here in Pelli's (1985) sense of intrinsic uncertainty, which characterizes the decision maker's uncertainty about the identity of the stimulus after experiencing it, as distinct from extrinsic or structural uncertainty, which is manipulated by the experimenter, through prior probabilities or some other manipulation.) The substantive part of this idea is that in the spherical model, unlike the circular model, the rate of evidence accumulation can be decoupled from the information in the stimulus. In both models, the norm of the drift rate, µ , determines the rate at which evidence accumulates towards the decision boundary. In the circular model, the drift rate norm represents stimulus information: For a pure noise stimulus, the norm will be zero and the process will be driven by diffusion noise alone and responses will be slow. In the spherical model, the norm represents the decision maker's propensity to respond, irrespective of the quality of the encoded stimulus information. When the stimulus is uninformative, as shown in Figure 3b, the drift-rate vector will be aligned with the X 3 t axis. Figure 4, which shows a vector field of motion strengths and directions, elaborates this idea: Weaker motion is represented by shorter vectors associated with points closer to the center of the circle and stronger motion is represented by longer vectors closer to the circumference. The vectors in the figure are a graphical representation of µ 1 and µ 2 , the first two components of the drift rate, µ. The third component, µ 3 , in the X 3 t direction, may vary independently of the other two components and of stimulus information.

What evidence is there for this kind of decoupling of stimulus information from the decision maker's overall propensity to respond? There are two bodies of the literature that support this idea. One involves the effects of urgency; the other involves the effects of stimulus intensity or value. Urgency has been linked theoretically to the idea that there may be a time cost to sampling evidence and it may be advantageous for decision makers to limit the time they spend on any decision in order not to lose the opportunity to consider other, potentially rewarding, alternatives (Drugowitsch et al. 2012;Malhotra et al., 2018).

This idea is especially plausible in situations in which the decision maker is confronted with a sequence of similar decision problems of varying difficulty that must be completed in a fixed time (Starns & Ratcliff, 2010;2012). Biologically, urgency has been linked to a component of neural activity that increases progressively from stimulus onset until the response, even in the absence of stimulus information. Churchland et al. (2008) identified a component of decision-related neural activity in lateral interparietal area of monkeys performing an RDM task that increased in this way even when the motion was incoherent, which they interpreted as a neural "urgency signal." Several authors have proposed models in which an urgency signal is combined either additively (Ditterich, 2006) or multiplicatively (Cisek et al., 2009) with the accumulating evidence. Additive representations are more consistent with the finding that urgency can be recorded in the absence of coherent motion; multiplicative representations combine more naturally with a model of the decision process as diffusion between absorbing boundaries.

Recent theoretical and empirical treatments of these kinds of models can be found in Trueblood et al. (2021) and Smith and Ratcliff (2021). An alternative to neural urgency is the idea that accumulating evidence races against a (stochastic) internal clock that sets a random internal deadline (Hawkins & Heathcote, 2021). The critical idea behind urgency models, however they are formulated, is that the propensity to respond can be decoupled from stimulus information. In the spherical diffusion model, this propensity is represented by the drift rate norm, µ , which can be nonzero, irrespective of the values of its first two components. As in other urgency models, the propensity to respond can be weak or strong, independent of the quality of the evidence in the stimulus. When formulated in this way the model has the attractive feature that there will be an identifiable component of urgency in the evidence entering decision process that is independent of stimulus information, as the neural findings of Churchland et al. suggest it should be.

The second, related, area concerns the effects of stimulus intensity or value. In both perceptual and value-based decision tasks in which pairs of alternatives are presented, RTs become shorter as the intensity or value of the alternatives is increased while the information, or relative value difference between them, is held constant. The effect has been found in perceptual tasks by Bose et al. (2020), Polanía et al. (2014), Ratcliff, Voskuilen and Teodorescu (2018), and Teodorescu et al. (2016) and in value-based decision tasks by Fontanesi et al. (2019) and Hunt et al. (2012). Pirrone et al. (2018) found monkeys made faster choices between two juice rewards when the alternatives had higher value than when they had lower value, even when the value difference between them was zero. Like urgency, various explanations have been proposed for the intensity/value effect and it is not our aim to try to distinguish between them. One explanation is that the intensity effect implies an independent accumulators model architecture, in which the absolute rather than the relative values of the evidence for the alternatives are accumulated (Teodorescu et al., 2016). Another is it reflects the effects of selective attention, which boosts the perceived value difference between attended and unattended items (Shevlin & Krajbich, 2021). A third is that an increase in intensity or value is accompanied by an increase in variability, either in drift rate or diffusion rate, which leads to shorter RTs in either instance . Like urgency, the effects of value/intensity imply a decoupling of stimulus information from the overall rate at which evidence accumulates. One way to implement this is in a model like the spherical diffusion model, in which the evidence space is of higher dimension than the response space and in which the drift rate encodes both overall value and value difference and where the overall value determines the propensity to respond.

Another attractive feature of the spherical diffusion model is that both it and the circular diffusion model may provide a characterization of subjective confidence. There is a rich literature on confidence that is beyond the scope of this article to review and, moreover, confidence judgments can be elicited in different ways, which seem to require different models. We focus on one narrow, but important, part of confidence. In two-choice decision tasks, a question of long standing has been how to characterize subjective confidence using random-walk or diffusion models, in which the decision variable is the relative evidence for the two alternatives. If evidence is accumulated by an independent-increments random-walk or diffusion process, as occurs in the Wiener diffusion process or in a log-likelihoodratio random walk (Laming, 1968(Laming, , 1979Bogacz et al. 2016), then the posterior probability of a response made at a particular boundary being correct will be constant, regardless of whether the response is fast or slow. Consequently, the accumulated evidence at the time of the response cannot provide a basis for confidence judgments (Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010). Vickers (1979) argued that the inability of random-walk models to account for confidence made them unattractive as models for decision making for this reason. As an alternative, he proposed a balance of evidence account of confidence, in which evidence for competing alternatives accumulates in separate totals, and confidence is a function of the difference between the winning and losing totals at the time of the response (Smith & Vickers, 1988).

Subsequent authors have argued that racing accumulator models like that of Vickers may be preferable to the standard diffusion model as models of the decision process because they provide a natural way to characterize confidence via the balance-of-evidence account (Van Zandt, 2015).

A possible way out of this dilemma is to assume, like the spherical diffusion model, that the dimensionality of the evidence accumulation space is greater than that of the response space and carries more information about the stimulus than just its categorical identity.
The benefits of this representation are easiest to see in relation to two-choice decisions.

Lilburn et al. (2019) studied two-choice decisions about grating patches in a visual workingmemory task in which observers judged whether the patches were rotated clockwise or anticlockwise from the vertical. They found that RT and accuracy could be well-described by the standard diffusion model but they also discussed a model in which decisions are made using a circular diffusion process applied to orientation space, in which the response circle is partitioned by decision bounds into regions associated with clockwise and anticlockwise responses. Smith (2019) and Smith and Corbett (2019) similarly proposed that categorical decisions can be modeled using continuous-outcome processes by partitioning the outcome space -2D in the former case and 4D in the latter -into discrete categories with decision bounds. These kinds of model might be appropriate, for example, for the n-choice RDM tasks studied by van Maanen et el. (2012). An assumption of all of these models is that the decision outcome, as represented by the hitting point of the diffusion process on the response circle, sphere, or hypersphere, represents the decision maker's best information about the identity of the stimulus. This is mapped via an appropriate response rule to a categorical response. Indeed, as described by Smith (2016), the hitting point on the decision boundary is the maximum-likelihood estimate of the orientation of the drift rate vector and an observer who responds based on the hitting point is a maximum-likelihood observer.

In Lilburn et al.'s task, the hitting point on the response circle is the observer's best estimate of the orientation of the stimulus relative to the vertical. Unlike the standard 1D diffusion model, in which vertical or horizontal responses are all made with a fixed posterior probability, the circular diffusion model with categorical bounds provides information about the strength of the evidence for a clockwise or anticlockwise response. Hitting points near the clockwise/anticlockwise boundary provide weak evidence for the chosen response;

hitting points far from it provide strong evidence. The richer representation of decision outcomes in the circular diffusion model potentially provides a way to characterize confidence -namely, as a function of the distance between the hitting point of the process on the decision boundary and the classification bounds that partition the outcome space into response categories. The same idea carries over to the spherical model: The azimuth of the hitting point represents the observer's estimate of the identity of the stimulus; the elevation of the hitting point represents the intrinsic uncertainty about it. The latter may plausibly be related to subjective confidence. Specifically, confidence will be a decreasing function of the distance of the hitting point from the equator: It will be maximal at the equator and minimal at the poles.

As noted earlier, Bae and Luck (2022) reported that confidence in the RDM task is higher for responses made in antipodal than orthogonal directions. The spherical diffusion model predicts such a relationship if the azimuthal (µ 1 , µ 2 ) component of drift rate is greater on antipodal than orthogonal response trials. For a given µ , if the azimuthal component of drift rate is large then the polar elevation of the drift rate vector will be small, which increases the probability that the process will hit the response sphere near the equator, which, by hypothesis, is associated with higher confidence. Drift-rate variability along the axis of motion forms part of all of the models we consider here: Large drift rates along the axis of motion increase the probability of responding in both the true and antipodal directions. Consequently, the models naturally predict the confidence relationship reported by Bae and Luck.

One of the most important empirical relationships that a model of confidence needs to satisfy is that higher confidence is associated with shorter decision times, under conditions of constant stimulus difficulty (Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010). Circular or spherical diffusion models with drift-rate variability naturally predict this relationship. Larger drift rates increase the precision of responding (Equation 3) and also result in shorter decision times. In the Lilburn et al. circular diffusion account of two-choice decisions, increased precision results in fewer responses made near the clockwise/anticlockwise classification boundary and consequently made with low confidence. The model thus predicts an inverse relationship between confidence and decision times. The spherical diffusion model predicts a similar relationship when there is across-trial variability in the azimuthal component of drift rate. If this component is large then the drift-rate norm will also be large. The hitting point on the response sphere will then be near the equator and responses will be made with high confidence. Decision times will also be short, so the model again predicts an inverse relationship between confidence and decision times.

It is not our aim here to try to evaluate either the circular or the spherical diffusion models as models of confidence. Rather, it is simply to articulate some of the theoretical implications of the idea that the dimensionality of the evidence accumulation and response spaces may be different and to suggest that the third dimension in the spherical model is a theoretically principled construct. We have argued, specifically, that it is not just an ad hoc device that allows the model to fit data but is related to a cluster of constructs that have proven useful in understanding other cognitive phenomena, namely, urgency, overall intensity or value, and confidence, and potentially provides testable predictions in these domains. The existence of these connections means the model is not narrowly paradigm-specific but connects productively with the broader cognitive literature.

div.head: Drift-Rate Bias
div.p: Many applications of continuous-outcome tasks, particularly in the VWM literature, have treated the stimulus space as isotropic or homogeneous and have assumed the pattern of responding is the same for stimuli in all parts of the space. More recently, several studies of continuous-outcome color judgments have shown that, rather than being isotropic, responses in some parts of the space -specifically, those associated with nameable colorsare more probable or more precise. These kinds of color category effects have been found in long-term memory (Persaud & Hemmer, 2016), visual working memory (Bae et al., 2015;Hardman et al., 2017), and in perceptual decisions with no delay (Bae et al., 2015). Ratcliff 2018and found that responses to preferred colors, as well as being more probable, were also faster. Blake et al. (1997) studied memory for dot motion and found strong biases for particular directions of motion. They considered several models to explain such biases, including that people are biased towards the cardinal axes, and concluded there was no common mechanism that could explain the patterns of bias in all participants. Instead, the biases they found were idiosyncratic and person-specific. Smith et al. 2020reported similarly idiosyncratic biases in hue judgments in an isoluminant color space (CIELUV space).

Categorical effects are not our primary focus here, but they occur in all continuousoutcome tasks we have so far studied and need to be incorporated into any model that aspires to completeness. The model for categorical effects we consider here is a variant of the model of Smith et al. (2020), which we have adapted to the spherical diffusion setting. The model assumes that categorical effects in continuous-outcome decisions reflect differences in the rate of evidence accumulation for stimuli in different parts of the 2D space, which are modeled as drift rate biases.

In the two-choice RT literature, biases in stimulus and response processes have both been studied. Response biases arise when one response is made with less evidence than the other, causing it to be made more rapidly and more frequently, and also more often in error. These kinds of biases are often found when the prior probabilities of the response alternatives are unequal (Dutilh et al., 2019) and are modeled in the two-choice diffusion model as an offset in the starting point for evidence accumulation (Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). Stimulus biases arise when evidence for one response accumulates more rapidly than the other, causing it to be made more rapidly and more frequently (Ashby, 1983), but not necessarily more often in error. In the two-choice diffusion model, stimulus biases are often implemented using a drift criterion, which determines the relative rates at which evidence for the two alternatives accumulates (Ratcliff & Smith, 2004). The model we consider here, which can be viewed as a continuous-outcome counterpart of a drift-criterion model, assumes that biases reflect differences in the drift rates for evidence accumulation for motion in particular directions. As discussed by , the model was motivated by both pragmatic and theoretical considerations. Pragmatically, it was motivated by the desire to develop a bias model that was compatible with the geometric and mathematical structure of the circular diffusion model. Theoretically, it was motivated by our belief that the dominant kinds of biases in tasks in which accuracy is stressed over speed are stimulus biases rather than response biases. Indeed, Bae (2021) reported a neural decoding study of categorical biases in location and orientation in visual working memory and concluded that they were encoded in the stimulus representations themselves rather than in the way judgments about stimuli are made. The stimulus-bias account of Smith et al. described below is consistent with the kind of biased representation view proposed by Bae. Figure 5 shows the drift-rate bias model of , as implemented in the spherical diffusion model. A stimulus with mean drift rate ν and polar angles θ and φ has a component ν = ν cos(φ) (in reparameterized coordinates) when projected onto the equatorial plane. The drift-rate biases are represented by a set of bias vectors, b i , i = 1, 2, . . ., in this plane. The number, locations, and norms of the bias vectors are assumed to be participant-specific. The component of drift rate in the equatorial plane is the sum of the stimulus-dependent component of drift rate, ν , and its nearest neighboring bias vector, b ' . The vectors add nose to tail in the usual manner of vector addition as shown in Figure 5b. This relationship has two consequences. First, it means that the evidence accumulation process will be biased in either a clockwise or anticlockwise direction towards the nearest bias vector. Second, when the azimuths of the stimulus and a bias vector coincide, the θ-components of the vectors will be collinear and the norm of their sum will be maximized. Evidence will accumulate more rapidly for such stimuli than would otherwise be the case and the associated RTs will be shorter and response precision will be greater. reported evidence for effects of this kind.

The model assumes that the effect of a bias vector located at ϕ on a stimulus located at θ is given by Proj(ν |b ' ), the projection of the stimulus on the bias vector exponentially attenuated by the difference in their azimuths as measured in the 1 − cos(•) circular distance metric (Mardia & Jupp, 1999). The attenuation of bias with distance is equal to ν exp{−α[1 − cos(θ − ϕ)}b ' , where α is a generalization parameter (Shepard, 1987) that characterizes the spatial extent of the bias. The full model assumes that the resulting distance-dependent biases are summed over all bias vectors in the stimulus space and that the θ-component of the biased drift rate vector is
div.formula: ν θ, bias = ν θ + ν ϕ exp {−α[1 − cos(θ − ϕ)]} b ϕ .(12)
div.p: Because the effects of bias decrease exponentially with distance, for most reasonable choices of α the sum in Equation 12 will be dominated by the bias vector that is closest to the stimulus.

div.head: Experimental Studies
div.p: The data we used to test the models come from two studies designed to evaluate the circular diffusion model in continuous-outcome random dot motion tasks. One of them was conducted at the University of Melbourne and the other was conducted at Trinity College,

Dublin. There were some procedural differences between the studies, most notably, the Dublin study was designed to investigate neural correlates of continuous-outcome decisions and electrophysiological recordings were made. These data will be presented elsewhere.

Other differences are described in the Method section below. Both studies used small-N designs (Smith & Little, 2018), in which large numbers of trials were collected from each participant, which allowed modeling of the joint distributions of RTs and decision outcomes for individual participants. We refer to the University of Melbourne and Trinity College studies as Experiment 1 and Experiment 2, respectively, and denote the participants in them with the prefixes "MP" and "DP." In Experiment 1, data were collected from four conditions in which the coherence of the motion was held constant at 30% and the durations of the stimuli were 176, 352, 529, or 706 ms. In Experiment 2, data were collected from two conditions in which stimuli were response-terminated and the coherence of the motion was either 25% or 50%. Data and code associated with these studies are publicly available at https://osf.io/8ptxd/ (Smith et al., 2022, February). The studies were not pregistered.

div.head: Method Participants
div.p: Data were collected from five young adults in Experiment 1 and six young adults in Experiment 2, all with normal or corrected-to-normal vision. In Experiment 1, data were collected from 9-10 experimental sessions, each of around one hour duration, yielding either 1296 or 1440 trials for each participant in each of the four exposure conditions. In Experiment 2, data were collected from 4-5 experimental sessions, each of around two hours duration, yielding from 505 to 773 trials for each participant in each of the two coherence conditions. Participants in Experiment 2 performed both a two-choice and a continuousoutcome task in alternate blocks; the two-choice data will be presented elsewhere. The participants in Experiment 1 did not have prior experience with the RDM task and were practiced for several sessions prior to data collection until their performance had stabilized.

Several of the participants in Experiment 2 had prior experience on the two-choice version of the task. Five of the six were practiced for one session; the sixth (who was highly accurate) performed the task with no prior practice.

div.head: Stimulus and Apparatus
div.p: Stimuli in Experiment 1 were presented on a 21" Sony Trinitron Multiscan CRT monitor with screen resolution 1, 280 × 1, 024 px and refresh rate of 85 Hz using a Cambridge

Research Systems ViSaGe framestore operating in BITS# mode controlled by a Dell workstation running Ubuntu Linux. 2 Software for the experiment was written in OCTAVE using PsychToolbox (Brainard, 1997) running at high priority. The stimuli were 2 × 2 pixel square dots, generated according to the "different" rule version of the random replotting algorithm of Scase, Braddick and Raymond (1996) fixation, but only dots within the aperture were displayed on the screen. In three out of every five frames a random selection of dots (25% or 50%) was displaced relative to their positions three frames earlier, creating a percept of motion. In the other two frames the dots moved incoherently. Dots that exited the patch were replotted on the opposite side of the patch on the next frame. Responses were made using a Thrustmaster T16000M FCS Joystick.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: In Experiment 1, a 1,000 ms fixation cross appeared after a 1,000 ms intertrial interval, which was followed by a variable-duration stimulus display. After stimulus offset, there was a further 505 ms delay before the appearance of a cursor (a bold "X"), which was the cue to respond. To make a decision, participants moved the cursor in the direction of the perceived motion to a point on a surrounding 5 deg annulus (measured from its inner edge). They were encouraged to make this movement as rapidly and ballistically as possible. The response time was taken to be the time of the midpoint of the movement from the home position to the entry into the response annulus. In Experiment 2, stimuli were presented following an 800 ms period of random noise, using the "seamless onset" manipulation of O'Connell and colleagues (Kelly, Corbett, & O'Connell, 2021). The purpose of this manipulation is to minimize artifacts associated with the stimulus onset in the evoked potential response in order to facilitate identification of a component associated with evidence accumulation. Participants were informed about the timing of the seamless onset manipulation but there were no external cues to indicate when the coherent motion began. The joystick used to record responses in Experiment 2 automatically returned to the neutral position when the participant released it. Pressure on the joystick caused the dots to disappear and a small, square cursor to appear, which showed the chosen direction of movement and remained visible until it had crossed the response circle. RT was taken as the time to initiate the movement (the disappearance of the dots and the appearance of the cursor). RT in Experiment 1 was measured from the occurrence of the response cue, while in Experiment 2 it was measured from the onset of coherent motion. These timing conventions have implications for the estimation and interpretation of nondecision times in the models, as discussed subsequently. To minimize anticipations in Experiment 1, on trials on which the participant moved the mouse within 150 ms after the response cue were flagged with a "too fast" error message and the trial was discarded. In Experiment 2, trials on which the participant moved the joystick during the first 150 ms after the onset of coherent motion were similarly flagged.

div.head: Mathematical Models
div.p: For both Experiment 1 and 2, we compared four main models: two versions of the circular diffusion model and two versions of the spherical diffusion model. Both versions of each model had across-trial variability in drift rate but one of them also had a mixture of stimulus-centered and antipodal drift rates, like the model of Bae and Luck (2019). In the models with antipodal drift rates, the mean drift rates were ν and −ν, with probabilities

(1 − π a ) and π a , respectively. We denote these four models as CIRC(η), CIRC(−ν, η), SPHR(η), and SPHR(−ν, η), respectively. In this nomenclature, the prefix CIRC or SPHR identifies the decision model as circular or spherical, while the arguments identify -in a purely symbolic way -the parameters used to explain bimodality. The η-models seek to explain bimodality through across-trial variability in drift rate alone; the (−ν, η)-models
seek to explain it through a combination of across-trial variability in drift rate and an antipodal component of mean drift rate. Table 1 lists the parameters used to fit the models to data.

To facilitate comparison of the circular and spherical models we parameterized drift rates in both models using the drift rate norm, ν , and also, in the case of the spherical model, the elevation (vertical component), φ, of the drift-rate vector above the equatorial plane. When the circular model is in canonical orientation, the drift rate norm is simply equal to its radial component ν 1 = ν . For the spherical model, ν 1 = ν cos(φ) and ν 3 = ν sin(φ), are the radial and vertical components of drift rate, respectively. The tangential component of drift rate for both models, ν 2 , was not a free parameter but was determined by the drift-rate bias model in Equation 12 and varied with location in the stimulus space. We allowed across-trial variability in the radial component of drift rate, η rad = η 1 , and also, in the spherical model, in the vertical component, η ver = η 3 . We considered the effects of variability in the tangential component of drift rate, η 2 , but, like Smith et al. (2020), we found it did not improve model fit and when it was allowed to

where N(µ; ν, η) is a multivariate normal distribution with mean ν and covariance matrix These biases, like those reported by Blake et al. (1997) and , appeared to be idiosyncratic rather than systematic. Our aim here was not to provide a detailed characterization of bias, so we adopted a minimal form of the drift-rate bias model of Equation 12 that was the same for all participants and models, in which there were four bias vectors, b ' , located at angles A ϕ , −π < A ϕ ≤ π, with a common amplitude b ϕ . We The manner in which stimuli were presented in both experiments leads to ambiguity about when evidence accumulation begins and the point from which RT should most appropriately be measured. In Experiment 1, stimuli were presented from 681 ms to 1,281 ms before the clock was started (the sum of the exposure duration and the responsecue interval) but there was a fixed trap for fast errors 150 ms after stimulus offset in all conditions. In Experiment 2, there was 800 ms of random noise prior to the onset of coherent motion. The upshot of these manipulations was that the estimates of nondecision times in the fitted models tended to be shorter than is typically found in diffusion models, which can range from a little under 180 ms to more than 650 ms (Kvam, 2019;Matzke & Wagenmakers, 2009;Ratcliff, 2018;. Our estimates of nondecision times were at or below the bottom of this range of estimates and in many instances were negative, likely because of the way stimuli were presented and RTs were recorded, which meant that some of the nondecision times may have fallen outside the measured response interval.

Although the interval between stimulus onset and response cue in Experiment 1 varied as a function of exposure duration, the minimum RTs, as indexed by the 0.1 RT distribution quantiles, were largely invariant across exposure conditions. If we interpret these quantiles as the times at which the fastest evidence accumulation processes finish then the invariance of the 0.1 quantile RTs can be interpreted as showing that the onset of evidence accumulation was delayed until presentation of the response cue.
