There was no evidence of truncation of the leading edges of the RT distributions due to responses made before the 150 ms fast-error trap, even at the longest exposures, suggesting that participants learned to withhold their responses until the response cue. 3 That they can do so has implications for how evidence accumulation is initiated and controlled. Smith et al. (2014) presented a release-from-inhibition model -which they modeled using an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process with a time-varying decay term that controlled response inhibition -in which the onset of evidence accumulation can be time-locked to an external event like a response cue, which can predict behavior of this kind.

For Experiment 2, the seamless-onset manipulation means the point at which evidence accumulation began was inherently ambiguous, but may have been as early as 800 ms before the stimulus. The idea that noise may be sampled from the prestimulus field prior to stimulus onset is a well-established one that was proposed to explain fast errors by Laming (1968). This kind of prestimulus sampling can be linked theoretically to the starting-point variability account of fast errors in the two-choice diffusion model (Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). In the case of the RDM task, a further complication arises from the fact that the processes that extract a perceptual representation of the motion may be slow-acting. Smith and Lilburn (2020) argued, based on the classical visual temporal sensitivity literature and a refit of the data from the blinded collaborative model recovery study of Dutilh et al. (2019), that computations of drift and diffusion rates in the RDM task may take place on a time scale of around 400-450 ms. In two-choice decision tasks, these time-varying processes can be modeled using integral equation methods , but drift and diffusion rates in the circular and spherical diffusion models are constant during a trial, as they are in the standard two-choice model. Consequently, these models are

3 The use of a fast error trap is critical to obtaining delayed evidence accumulation. In two earlier experiments using a mouse-movement task with no fast-error trap (whose data we discarded), there was an obvious truncation of the leading edge of the RT distributions associated with responses made before the clock started.

limited in their ability to represent changes in the evidence state from one value to another during a trial. Because of these considerations, we elected to model the distributions of RT exactly as they were measured and we denote the estimated nondecision time in the model as T ′ er and refer to it as the residual nondecision time. The terminology is intended to highlight the fact that in both experiments it is probable that some of the nondecision time fell outside the measurement interval and our use of a special symbol to denote the remaining, measured part serves to emphasize this fact. We consider the implications of time-varying stimulus processing in the Discussion.

In many studies of diffusion models, nondecision time is assumed to vary randomly across trials (Matzke & Wagenmakers, 2009, Appendix A). In our initial implementation of the models we also made this assumption, but we found it did not systematically improve fits, so we omitted it from the final models. Typically, the effects of nondecision time variability are most pronounced and the benefits of including it are most evident in speedstress tasks where responding is fast. In two-choice psychophysical tasks in which accuracy is stressed, we have often found that nondecision time variability makes, at most, a marginal contribution to model fit. omitted it from their study of continuousoutcome color decisions for the same reason we omitted it here.

div.head: Results
div.p: Individual differences There were large individual differences in RT and accuracy in both experiments and in whether or not bimodal error distributions were obtained. Three participants in Experiment 1 showed pronounced secondary modes; the remaining two provided some, equivocal, evidence for secondary modes. Three participants in Experiment 2 showed some evidence of secondary modes, although they were not as pronounced as in Experiment 1. A fourth had heavy-tailed error distributions with no evidence of a secondary mode. The remaining participants were very accurate and did not have heavytailed error distributions. The participants who showed secondary modes are the interesting ones for our purposes and are the ones whom we expected to be most diagnostic in testing between models.

Fitting the models to data We fit the models to data by maximum likelihood, where the likelihood, L(θ, T ), associated with decision outcome θ and response time T , is L(θ, T ) = dP t (θ T ), where dP t (θ T ) is given by Equation 4, for specified values of the model parameters. To do so, we minimized minus the sum of the log-likelihoods (−LL), where
div.formula: LL = i j log L(θ ij , T ij ),(14)
div.p: for each participant individually using the Nelder-Mead simplex algorithm in Matlab (fminsearch). In this expression, θ ij and T ij are the decision outcome and RT for the jth trial in the ith condition, respectively. As discussed by Ratcliff and Tuerlinckx (2002), a problem with maximum-likelihood fitting of RT data is the presence of outlier observations to which the model assigns zero likelihood, which can create convergence problems and distort the fit. We dealt with this problem using the procedure of , which assigned a value of L = 0.05 to any observation to which the model assigned zero likelihood (dP t (θ T ) = 0). The effect of this procedure was to downweight the effect of any observation that fell too far from the rest of the data. This stabilized the fitting procedure and avoided the convergence problems to which maximum likelihood is otherwise prone. We compared models using the Akaike information criterion (AIC; Akaike, 1974) and the Bayesian information criterion (BIC; Schwarz, 1978), which penalize models for their numbers of free parameters,
div.formula: AIC = −2LL max + 2m BIC = −2LL max + m log N,(15)
div.p: where m is the number of free parameters in the model and N is the total number of trials on which the likelihood is based. Table 2 shows the fits statistics for the four models to the data from the individual participants in Experiment 1. Figures 6 to 8 show the fits of the model SPHR(−ν, η) to the data from four of the five participants, which is the best-fitting model in each case. We have limited ourselves to showing fits for the most theoretically interesting participants in order to keep the figures compact. Selected conditions for the remaining participant are shown in Figure 9, which compares the fits of SPHR(−ν, η) and CIRC(−ν, η). Figure 6 shows the marginal distributions of decision outcomes and RT for the four exposure In interpreting the fit statistics in Table 2, the reader is reminded that log-likelihoods can only be compared across models for an individual participant but they cannot be compared across participants. Differences in the log-likelihoods for different participants cannot be used to infer whether a model fits one participant better than another because the summed log-likelihood depends both on the fit and on the variance of the fitted distributions. The latter determines which observations make positive contributions and which make negative contributions to the log-likelihood. Table 2 shows a very consistent pattern of performance of the models across all participants. The spherical models performed better than the circular models and the two- given azimuth, θ, by varying φ, which allows them to predict a wider range of decision outcomes than do their circular counterparts. When combined with across-trial variability in drift rates, the models predict Q × Q plots that better correspond to those found in data. predicts the slow-error pattern in all conditions, to an increasing degree as the task gets harder.

div.head: Experiment 1
div.p: The predicted Q × Q functions in Figure 6 are not determined solely by the drift-rate variability parameter, η rad , but also depend on the drift-rate bias model, which predicts Figure 8, but the log-likelihood of the resulting model was poorer. We also found that the distribution of decision outcomes for this participant could be better captured qualitatively by a generalization of the model that allowed the elevation of the drift-rate vector, φ, to differ for the veridical and antipodal components of the drift rate. If we view the elevation of the drift-rate vector as being a reflection of the decision-maker's uncertainty about the encoded representation of the stimulus, then the psychological interpretation of this generalization of the model is that people are more likely to mistake the direction of motion within the optic flow field on trials when they are uncertain about the encoded stimulus. This generalization of the model seems plausible to us, but we have restricted ourselves to reporting only the simplest versions of the spherical models, in which there is a single elevation parameter. Table 3 shows the estimated parameters for the best-fitting model, SPHR(−ν, η). There is substantial heterogeneity in the estimated parameters that reflects the substantial individual differences in the performance on the task, as shown in Figure 6. For all participants, however, the mean drift-rate norms, ν 1 through ν 4 , varied over a fairly narrow range, consistent with the fact there were only fairly small differences in performance as a function of stimulus duration, despite the large range of durations that we used. For most participants (with the exception of MP5), variability in the radial component of drift rate, η rad , was larger than variability in the vertical component, η ver , which is a reflection of the role played by the radial component in predicting slow errors and double-bowing. The radial component of drift-rate variability and the drift-rate bias model of Equation 12 together determine the shapes of the predicted joint distributions.

The question of how much of the across-trial variability in drift rates is attributable to stimulus-specific factors like those in the drift-bias model and how much is attributable to endogenous factors like fluctuations in attention and alertness has been debated in both psychology and neuroscience. Ratcliff, Voskuilen, and McKoon (2018) used a double-pass procedure to investigate this question in several different two-choice decision tasks. For most of their tasks, stimulus factors and endogenous factors both appeared to contribute to the estimated drift-rate variance, but for the RDM task, most of the variability was due to differences among stimuli. In the RDM task, the agreement in double-pass performance closely matched the agreement predicted from the estimated drift-rate variance in the diffusion model, but in the other tasks the estimated variance exceeded what would have been predicted if it had arisen from stimulus factors alone. Our results similarly suggest that a substantial part of the across-trial variability in drift rate, as reflected in the shapes of the Q × Q plots, can be attributed to differences in the drift rate for stimuli in different parts of the stimulus space, as indicated by the stimulus-specific error and RT effects in Figure 8, which the model attributes to drift-rate biases. However, they do not allow us

to identify exactly what proportion of drift-rate variability is due to stimulus factors and what proportion is due to endogenous factors in the cognitive system, which would have required a double-pass procedure like the one used by ).

Because of the uncertainty about when evidence accumulation began relative to when the clock was started in Experiment 1, we allowed the residual nondecision time parameter, T ′ er , to vary freely in the fits and did not impose an a priori constraint that it should be positive. As can be seen in Table 3, most of the estimates of T ′ er were small and in all but one instance they were negative. Taken at face value, these estimates imply that evidence accumulation for these participants began before presentation of the cue to respond. As the cue always occurred at a predictable time after stimulus offset and the participants were all highly practiced, this kind of strategic adaptation to the temporal characteristics of the task seems plausible. It is also the case, however, that the criterion estimates, a, in the best-fitting spherical models tended to be larger than those in the circular models, and larger criteria are associated with a rightward shift of the predicted RT distributions, so the associated estimates of nondecision time will then be shorter. Consistent with this, estimates of T ′ er in the circular models tended to be longer than in the spherical models and most were positive, ranging from -0.02 s to 0.09 s. We regard the estimates of T ′ er in Table 3 as reasonable ones given the nature of the paradigm, but to ensure the rankordering of the models in Table 2 was not an artifact of compensatory differences in the nondecision times for circular and spherical models we refit the spherical models with T ′ er fixed equal to the estimated T ′ er for the corresponding circular models. The fits worsened a little quantitatively when constrained in this way but the overall qualitative properties of the fits were the same and the picture in Table 2 was unchanged. Table 4 shows the fit statistics for the four models to the individual participant data for Experiment 2. Figures 10 to 12 show fits of the best model to the marginal and joint distributions of decision outcomes and RT, and the stimulus-dependent signed error and median RT, respectively. In comparison to Experiment 1, RTs in Experiment 2 were longer and the secondary modes, in those cases in which they were found, were less pronounced.

div.head: Experiment 2
div.p: Two participants (DP1 and DP2) show clear secondary modes; two others (DP4 and DP6)

show heavy tails, with a hint of a secondary mode in DP6, and the remaining two (DP3 and DP6) were very accurate with no probability mass outside the central region. The long RTs in Experiment 2 were likely due to the seamless onset manipulation, which introduces uncertainty into when the stimulus begins. We suspect that the larger secondary modes in Experiment 1 were due to its greater reliance on visual working memory: The stimuli in Experiment 2 remained present until a decision was made whereas in Experiment 1 decisions were based on memory representations formed during the prior exposure period.

Apart from the differences in RT, another feature of Experiment 2 that differs from Experiment 1 is the shifts in the leading edges (the .1 quantiles) of the RT distributions in the Q × Q plots in Figure 11. In Experiment 1, the leading edges of the joint distributions showed little change as a function of response accuracy, in agreement with other continuousoutcome data we have analyzed (e.g. . In contrast, for three of the participants in Experiment 2 (DP1, DP2, and DP6) the .1 quantile RTs are shortest for the most accurate responses and become longer as accuracy decreases. Participant DP4

shows the opposite pattern: The longest .1 quantile RTs are associated with the most accurate responses. The remaining participants do not have a sufficient range of accuracy to allow inferences about the shapes of the .1 quantile functions. We think the shapes of the Q × Q functions in Figure 11 are likely the result of uncertainty associated with the seamless-onset manipulation. All six participants show a slow error pattern in the upper (.5 to .9) quantiles of the Q×Q plots, but for DP4 in the .1 quantile this pattern is reversed.

The reversal for DP4 likely reflects premature sampling of the kind proposed by Laming (1968), in which evidence accumulation is driven by noise from the prestimulus display, leading to fast, inaccurate responses on some trials. Note. m=number of free parameters, bold face denotes the best-fitting model.

The reasons for the slow errors in the .1 quantiles of DP1, DP2, and DP6 are less clear but we think they reflect the lack of an onset transient in the display to initiate evidence Yantis and Jonides (1984), in which discriminative information is carried by the removal of stimulus features rather than their addition, lead to long RTs and reduced accuracy (Sewell & Smith, 2012). Sewell and Smith argued that the lack of onset transients leads to inefficiency or imprecision in the allocation of attention, which results in longer RTs -including a shift in the leading edge of the RT distributions -and lower accuracy, and proposed a time-varying diffusion model based on the integrated system model of Smith and Ratcliff (2009) to account for them.
We think it likely that the seamless-onset manipulation produces similar imprecision in the allocation of attention, which affects the initiation of evidence accumulation.
In comparison to Experiment 1, in which the best-fitting model for all participants was the spherical model, SPHR(−ν, η), the results for Experiment 2 were more equivocal.

Again, the spherical models performed uniformly better than the circular models, but for half of the participants the best model was SPHR(−ν, η), which has an antipodal drift-rate component, and for the other half it was SPHR(η), which has drift-rate variability only.

This difference corresponds to the patterns of decision outcomes in Figure 10: Participants with a secondary mode were best-fit by a model with an antipodal drift-rate component and those no secondary mode were best-fit by a model without it. Overall, the models do a fairly good job of capturing the diverse and challenging pattern of data represented by the marginal distributions in Figure 10, the joint distributions in Figure 11, and the stimulus-dependent error and RT effects in Figure 12. Like Experiment 1, the best-fitting model with drift bias (either SPHR(−ν, η) or SPHR(η), depending on the participant), provided a better account of the data for all participants according to both the AIC and the BIC.

Despite the comparatively good fit, the seamless-onset manipulation may have introduced time dependencies into the stimulus encoding process that are not represented in our models. Such dependencies may be particularly pronounced in the RDM task in which there is evidence that temporal integration of the motion signal leads to time-varying drift and diffusion rates . Some of the misfits in Figure 11 -such as the overprediction of the slow-error pattern for DP6 and the pronounced double-bowing pattern for DP1 -may be a reflection of the limited ability of our models to capture these sorts of time dependencies. Nevertheless, the ability of the models to capture the complex patterns of accuracy and RTs in the individual data is fairly impressive.

Like Experiment 1, there was a tendency for the best-fitting residual nondecision times to go negative, as shown in Table 5. As in Experiment 1, negative residual times are not implausible: Psychologically, they characterize an evidence accumulation process that begins before the clock is started and, indeed, Devine et al. (2019) found electrophysiological evidence that this occurs with the seamless-onset manipulation. But, as we discussed in relation to Experiment 1, short nondecision times can also be a consequence of fitting a family of RT distributions with models with large decision criteria and, as Table 5 shows, the decision criteria in the best-fitting spherical models were uniformly large. To ensure that the rank-ordering of the models in Table 4 was not an artifact of compensatory differences in the nondecision times for circular and spherical models, we again refit the spherical models with T ′ er fixed equal to the estimates for the corresponding circular models. For five of the six participants the comparative performance of the T ′ er -constrained models was unchanged: In each instance, the spherical models were preferred to the circular models.

The exception was DP5, for whom T ′ er for CIRC(η) was fairly long (0.148 s). For DP5, the negative log-likelihood for SPHR(η) with T ′ er = 0.148 was worse than the corresponding statistic for CIRC(η) in Table 5 (−LL = 66.3), but when we refit it with T ′ er set equal to the mean of the estimates for the circular model, the fit was better than the fit of that model (−LL = 20.3). We conclude that the better fits of the spherical models in Table 4 do not depend on nondecision times being allowed to become negative, because when they are constrained to have the same nondecision times as those in the circular models they continue to do better than them. Those nondecision times are themselves short, but, as we have emphasized, they are plausible in the context of the seamless-onset paradigm in which there is uncertainty about when evidence accumulation begins.

div.head: Parameter recovery and model identification
div.p: Given the complexity of our models, there is a question of whether, and how well, their parameters can be identified in data. On the one hand, the joint distributions provide a rich and and detailed empirical structure to constrain the estimates; on the other hand, the number of free parameters is large and they enter into the models in a highly nonlinear way.

To investigate the parameter recovery properties of the model we carried out a simulation study, in which we simulated multiple realizations of the experimental design of Experiment 1 using the Euler method (Brown et al., 2006) with a step size of 0.001 s, using the same number of trials as used in the experiment, and using parameters loosely based on those used to fit the data. We focus on the model SPHR(−ν, η), which was the most complex model structurally and had the greatest number of free parameters. Figure 13 summarizes the results of this study. The parameters used in the simulation, shown in the caption of Figure 13, resulted in a moderate-sized secondary mode, slightly larger than that in the low coherence condition in Bae and Luck's (2019) data in Figure 1, a dished Q × Q plot with some evidence of double bowing, as shown in the lower panel of Figure 3d, and a pronounced category structure. We used a greater range of drift rate norms than we found empirically in order to investigate whether drift rates could be accurately recovered across a range of values, and a positive rather than negative value of T er to investigate whether the negative values in Table 3 were an artifact of the model. The distributions of parameter estimates in Figure 13 were based on 25 complete simulations of Experiment 1, which were fit by independently and randomly perturbing each of the generating parameters by ±75% to use as starting parameters in fminsearch. 4 As Figure 13 shows, the parameters were well recovered in the fits to the simulated data, including T er , which did not show any evidence of estimation bias. In all instances, the range of estimated values is narrow, with few outliers, and the medians of the estimates are close to the generating values. There is a slight but systematic tendency for the drift rate norms to underestimate their generating values and a corresponding tendency for the decision criterion also to be slightly underestimated. These estimation biases may be a reflection of the approximation of a continuous diffusion process by a discrete-time random walk, which, on average, must travel further before stopping than the corresponding continuous process (Smith, 1990). In general, however, the parameters of the model were well recovered and there is no evidence of nonidentifiability, which would result in long ridges of equal likelihood in the likelihood surface, in which parameters could be traded off against each other. These kinds of tradeoffs would manifest themselves as large variances in the associated estimates. The only place in which there evidence tradeoffs may have occurred was in the identification of the drift-rate bias vectors A 1 and A 2 . Figure 13 shows the location of the first of these vectors was underestimated and the second was overestimated. As these vectors were only 0.5 rad (29 deg) apart and the effect of the difference between them was smeared by the exponential similarity gradient (α = 2.5), it is unsurprising that these parameters were individually difficult to identify. The marginal and joint distributions and the stimulus-dependent angular error, corresponding to Figure 7, 8, and 9 (which we have not reproduced), showed there was a close agreement between the simulated data and predictions for the model for all 25 data sets. We carried out a similar parameter recovery study for the model CIRC(−ν, η), which we have not reproduced, using the best-fitting parameters of the circular model to the simulated data from the spherical model as generating parameters, the results of which were at least as good as those in Figure 13.

We also carried out a model identification study to ascertain how well the circular and spherical models were able to reproduce each other's data. We focused on the twocomponent models CIRC(−ν, η) and SPHR(−ν, η) as the better-performing models of each class. To this end, we cross-fit the two models to the two sets of simulated data used in algorithm that parallelized the model across stimulus angles.

the parameter recovery study. The simulated data for the circular model had marginal distributions of errors and RT and category effects that were virtually indistinguishable from those of the spherical model, but had more deeply-dished and double-bowed Q × Q functions, like those shown in Figure 9, for the reasons discussed there. When the models were fitted to their own data, the average log-likelihood for CIRC(−ν, η) was −LL = 7, 293 and for SPHR(−ν, η) was −LL = 4, 804. (Readers are again reminded that the relative magnitudes of the log-likelihoods does not show the relative performance of the models because the maximum likelihoods achievable for different data depend on their variances.)

For the cross-fit models, the average log-likelihood for CIRC(−ν, η) fit to the spherical data was −LL = 5, 586 and for SPHR(−ν, η) fit to the circular data was −LL = 7, 272. At the level of the individual simulations, for all 25 sets of simulated spherical data the model was better fit by the spherical than the circular model according to the log-likelihood, the AIC, and the BIC. For the 25 sets of simulated circular data, the majority were better fit by the spherical model: Eighteen were better fit by the log-likelihood and the AIC; seventeen were better fit by the BIC. The spherical model can predict deeply-dished Q × Q plots like those in Figure 9 with small values of the drift rate elevation parameter, φ, that is, with drift rate vectors that are in or close to the equatorial plane. The model identification study confirms the picture obtained from the fits to the data of Experiments 1 and 2. The circular diffusion model cannot easily capture the typical pattern of empirical data in our experiments, which involves a secondary mode, category effects, and a moderately dished or double-bowed joint distribution. The spherical model can capture this pattern, as well as the more extreme Q × Q functions predicted by the circular model. The model identification study shows that the spherical model is appreciably more flexible than the circular model, but this flexibility appears to be necessary and, as we argued previously, it is theoretically principled.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this article we have provided a characterization of the decision processes involved in the continuous-outcome RDM task and a comparison of alternative models of the secondary, "shadow" mode that many participants in this task display. This is not the only setting in which bimodal outcome distributions have been found in continuous-outcome tasks, but it is a theoretically interesting one and provides an important test-bed for models like the circular and spherical diffusion models that do not naturally predict bimodalility. Kvam and Turner (2021), in their analysis of the relationship between the circular diffusion model and Ratcliff's SDCM, suggested that bimodality could arise if evidence is accumulated in a space that is of higher dimensionality than the response space. Our development of the spherical diffusion model was inspired, in part, by their analysis and by the earlier development of the hyperspherical diffusion model by Smith and Corbett (2019). Although Kvam and Turner showed that a spherical diffusion model could predict bimodal outcome distributions and plausible-looking marginal distributions of RT, they did not consider the joint outcome-RT distributions predicted by their model. As highlighted in Figure 9 here, a model can predict plausible-looking marginal distributions but nevertheless fail badly to account for the joint distributions. We have emphasized the qualitative properties of the joint distributions, as characterized by Q × Q plots, as a primary benchmark that any credible model must account for.

As well as needing to account for the joint distributions of decision outcomes and RT, we emphasized the importance of accounting for stimulus anisotropies in accuracy and RT -that is, for variations in performance in different parts of the stimulus space. We have shown that a fairly minimal implementation of the drift-bias model of was able to account for much of the systematic variation in decision outcomes and RT as a function of motion direction, as shown in Figures 8 and 12. The effects of drift-rate bias augment those of drift-rate variability, as represented by the η rad and η ver parameters, and increase the slow-error or double-bowed pattern predicted by the models. Like the standard diffusion model for two-choice decisions, the circular and spherical diffusion models clearly distinguish between within-trial and across-trial variability. Within-trial The need for across-trial variability in evidence-accumulation models has been a subject of ongoing debate in psychology and neuroscience, but the existence of the kinds of stimulus anisotropies that we and others have identified (Bae et al., 2015;Blake et al., 1997;Hardman et al. 2017;Persaud & Hemmer, 2016;Ratcliff, 2018) clearly shows that this kind of variability will be present whenever data are marginalized or aggregated across stimuli and that its effects need to represented in a complete model.

div.head: Circular versus spherical diffusion models
div.p: Our primary theoretical contribution in this article has been to provide a formal, mathematical characterization of the spherical diffusion model and to show that the addition of the extra dimension endows it with some properties that may be useful in applications like the one we have considered here. Kvam and Turner (2021) conceptualized the extra dimension as being one coordinate of a multidimensional evidence accumulation space, which they related to the multidimensional scaling representation of the stimulus domain, but here, where we are studying planar motion, the stimulus domain is inherently two-dimensional. As we discussed earlier, we consider the extra dimension in the continuous-outcome motion task to be a representation of the decision maker's uncertainty about the encoded stimulus, which could conceivably be related to subjective confidence.

A number of continuous-outcome tasks, including visual working memory and decisions about noise-perturbed color patches produce peaked, high-tailed distributions of decision outcomes, which are often characterized as a mixture of stimulus-driven and guessing processes. characterized the heavy tails as reflecting an encoding-failure process, in which the identity of the encoded stimulus is random, and uniformly distributed around the circle. The spherical diffusion model provides another way to represent such processes: The drift-rate vector on encoding-failure trials points towards the north pole, leading to responses that are uniformly distributed around the circle.

We found that the relative performance of the four models, CIRC(η), CIRC(−ν, η), SPHR(η), and SPHR(−ν, η) depended both on the experimental task and on the individual participant. In Experiment 2, in which the secondary modes were small or absent, the data for five of the six participants could be accounted for satisfactorily by the simplest of the four models, CIRC(η), the circular diffusion model with across-trial variability in drift rate only. The exception was DP1, who showed the largest secondary modes of the six. For DP1, the level of drift-rate variability needed to predict the secondary mode produced a double-bowed pattern that substantially exceeded that in the data. For moderate levels of drift-rate variability, which produce Q × Q plots that resemble the data, the model predicted heavy-tailed distributions of decision outcomes but no secondary modes. These kinds of effects were much more apparent in Experiment 1, where larger secondary modes were found. The simpler circular diffusion models had difficulty in accounting for the data from Experiment 1.

One of the -to us -unexpected findings was that the circular diffusion model with an antipodal drift-rate component, CIRC(−ν, η), should have difficulty in accounting for these data. As commented by Bae and Luck (2019), decision-outcome data like those in Figure 1 are readily fit by a mixture of von Mises distributions. However, the need to account for RT data, especially at the level of the joint distributions, greatly increases the theoretical challenge. For these data, the spherical diffusion model with an antipodal driftrate component, SPHR(−ν, η), tended to be the best model. The success of this model is attributable to the additional component of drift-rate elevation, φ, which leads to predicted Q × Q plots that are less obviously double-bowed and more closely resemble those found in the data. Versions of this model provided a fairly good account of all aspects of the data from all of the participants in the two experiments considered here.

div.head: Time inhomogeneous evidence accumulation
div.p: A limitation of our mathematical models were that they assumed that the process of evidence accumulation is time-homogeneous or time-invariant, that is, the drift and diffusion rates remain constant throughout an experimental trial. Like the standard diffusion model for two-choice decisions, the assumption of time-homogeneity is needed to derive the expressions for the joint densities in Equation 4 to 6. In two-choice decision tasks, time-inhomogeneous stimulus representations can be modeled mathematically using models, there is some evidence that the RDM task may be an exception and may be better characterized using time-inhomogeneous models. found that the selective influence violations (violations of assumed parameter invariance across experimental conditions) in the two-choice diffusion model in the blinded validity study of the RDM task by Dulith et al. (2019) were reduced when they used a model with time-inhomogeneous drift and diffusion rates with an integration time of around 400 ms. They attributed the time inhomogeneity to perceptual integration by the motion system, which determines the strength of evidence entering the decision process, as distinct from the integration of evidence in the decision process itself.

Their estimated 400 ms integration time is consistent with estimates reported by Holmes et al. (2016) who modeled decisions about changing stimulus information in the RDM task using a piecewise linear ballistic accumulator model and found that the change in the evidence entering the decision process lagged the stimulus by around 400 ms. However, Ratcliff and McKoon (2008) found that the standard diffusion model provided a good fit to data from the RDM task with appropriately chosen values of nondecision time and nondecision time variability. This is consistent with the analysis of Smith et al. (2014), who showed that a time-inhomogeneous two-choice diffusion model in which the drift and diffusion rates are proportional to one another behaves like a time-homogeneous model shifted to the right on the time axis.

These considerations are particularly relevant to the seamless onset manipulation in Experiment 2, in which stimuli were preceded by several hundred milliseconds of incoherent motion. If, as the results of Holmes et al. (2016) and the analysis of suggest, the drift and diffusion rates in the RDM task depend on the output of a slow perceptual integration process, then the drift rate in the task is likely to be a timevarying function whose initial segment is a mixture of incoherent and coherent motion.

To evaluate the effects of these kinds of time-inhomogeneities, we simulated the spherical diffusion model with a seamless onset manipulation. A psychophysically realistic model of drift rate would represent it as the output of a linear filter with a long integration time (Smith, 1995;Smith & Ratcliff, 2009, but as our concern was simply to evaluate the qualitative effect of time-inhomogeneity on the predictions of the model, we implemented it in a simple way, by assuming that the drift rate norm ramped up linearly from zero to a maximum of µ at time t = 0.4 s. Because there is a seamless transition from incoherent to coherent motion in the experimental manipulation, we assumed that the diffusion rate remained constant throughout a trial. Figure 14 shows the results of fitting the spherical diffusion model SPHR(−ν, η) to data simulated from a process with a ramped-on drift rate. We used the same experimental design as we used in the parameter recovery study (i.e., a version of the design of Experiment 1), but with 5,000 simulated trials per condition to provide a finer-grained characteriza-tion of the relationship between the simulated and fitted distributions. The figure shows only the easiest and hardest conditions for compactness because the other two conditions showed the same features. The figure shows that, in agreement with the results of Smith et al. (2014) and the fits of Ratcliff and McKoon (2008), a time-homogeneous model fits the data generated by a time-inhomogeneous process well. Numerically, the fit is a bit worse than fits of the model to data generated by a time-homogeneous process 197 vs. −LL = 1, 686, with the usual caveat about comparing likelihoods across different data sets), but qualitatively there is little to distinguish them. The figure shows that the time-inhomogeneous model does an excellent job of accounting for the marginal and the joint distributions. Because the drift rate in the simulated process was ramped on while the diffusion rate was constant, we expected the early part of the process to be dominated by noise and that there would be discrepancies between the simulated and predicted 0.1 distribution quantiles as a result, but, surprisingly, this was not the case. Rather, all of the quantiles in the Q × Q plot are well-captured by the model. The reason for this counterintuitive behavior is presumably because the model becomes time-homogeneous after 400 ms, and the fastest responses are all slower than this (the empirical 0.1 quantiles are around 500 ms). Consequently, the hitting-time dynamics of the process are essentially those of a time-homogeneous process.

The most obvious difference between the simulated and fitted models are the estimated parameters. We allowed the nondecision time in the fitted model to be uniformly distributed with range, s t . The nondecision time parameters in the generating model were T er = 0.07 s and s t = 0 s; the estimated parameters in the fitted model were T er = 0.166 s and s t = 0.124 s. Consistent with our earlier observation, unmodeled time-inhomogeneity increases estimated nondecision time mean and variability. These effects are noteworthy, because our nondecision time estimates were uniformly short, which we attributed to evidence accumulation starting before the clock. Any inhomogeneity in the underlying process not represented in the model would tend to act in the opposite direction to this effect and increase the estimated nondecision times. If so, then our model fits might have underestimated the extent to which evidence accumulation began before the clock. Apart from nondecision times, the other aspect of the simulation that merits comment is that the drift rate norms and decision criteria in Figure 14 all underestimated their generating values.

This was also the case in the parameter recovery study, but, at least in the case of the drift rates, the underestimate is greater, suggesting that the model underestimates the rate of evidence accumulation when the early part of the process is time-inhomogeneous. In general, however, the results of the simulation in Figure 14 are reassuring. Even when the process is time-inhomogeneous in its initial segment, the time-homogeneous model captures its essential structure with a high degree of fidelity.

div.head: Visual mechanisms of ambiguous motion perception
div.p: We remarked earlier that the success of a model with a mixture of antipodal drift rates suggests the input to the decision process is an opponent-process motion percept of some kind. There are several different models for motion perception in the vision literature that might plausibly produce antipodal motion percepts. Anstis proposed that the perceived dot motion in Julesz stereograms could be mediated by edge detectors (Anstis & Mackay, 1980) and Geisler (1999) proposed they may be mediated by motion streaks on the retina.

However, one of the most influential is the class of motion energy models, which can be implemented neurally with oriented visual filters (Adelson and Bergen, 1985). Figure 15 shows how a motion energy mechanism, which senses the presence and direction of motion, can be built up from low-level visual filters in this way. As a building block of such a model, Figure 15a shows a separable spatiotemporal filter, which has a center-surround spatial response function, consisting of an excitatory center and inhibitory flanks, and a biphasic temporal impulse response function. At short times, the center response of the filter is excitatory; at longer times it becomes inhibitory. The temporal response of the surround is the opposite of this. The spatiotemporal response of the filter as a whole is the product of its spatial and temporal response functions, which is summarized by the pattern of plus and minus signs in the rectangle on the left.

The separable impulse response function in Figure 15a implements an oriented spatiotemporal filter, that is, a filter whose response has a particular direction in space and time. The pattern of pluses and minuses can be viewed as weights that characterize the kinds of stimuli to which the filter responds. The filter in the figure responds maximally to a patch of positive contrast that moves from left to right at a speed commensurate with the temporal impulse response of the filter. Importantly, however, it also responds to a patch that moves from right to left at the same speed. This problem of "direction blindness" was identified by Adelson and Bergen (1985) and caused them to reject the simple separable filter as a model for motion perception. To rectify the direction blindness of the separable filter, and the related problem that it cannot distinguish a dark patch moving left from a light patch moving right, they proposed that filters be combined in quadrature pairs.

As shown in Figure 15b, in a quadrature pair filter, one of the components has an evensymmetric spatial response and the other has an odd-symmetric response. The outputs of the even-symmetric and odd-symmetric components of the filter are squared and summed.
The resultant sum is a measure of the motion energy in the stimulus and, unlike the sim-ple separable filter of Figure 15a, it is sensitive to the presence and direction of motion.

The appeal of these kinds of models is that they can be synthesized mathematically from simple components that have the same kinds of spatiotemporal response characteristics as cortical cells. Although there are other kinds of motion model, such as Reichardt detectors, which respond to spatiotemporal correlations (van Santen, & Sperling, 1984), Adelson and Bergen showed that such detectors are formally equivalent to motion energy models.

For our purposes, Adelson and Bergen's rejected separable spatiotemporal filter is of theoretical interest because its properties are reminisicent of the behavior of the participants in our experiments. The filter is sensitive to the orientation of the optic flow field that characterizes the motion, but is blind to the direction of motion within the field. A plausible model for the visual mechanisms that drive the decision process in our task is a motion energy model in which the individual components of quadrature pairs are noiseperturbed and vary randomly and independently in strength from trial to trial. On some trials only one member of a pair, but not both, respond with sufficient strength to elicit a percept of motion. On these trials, the percept will be ambiguous in precisely the way the data show.

A related theoretical question addressed by our modeling results concerns how such ambiguous percepts are distributed across trials. We compared models with unimodal and bimodal distributions of drift rates: CIRC(η) and SPHR(η) versus CIRC(−ν, η) and SPHR(−ν, η). The first two models assume that the radial component of drift rate has a unimodal distribution with mean ν rad and standard deviation η rad . On some trials the sign of the drift rate sampled from the distribution will be the opposite to ν rad and the process will drift towards the antipodal point on the response boundary. The other two models assume that on some trials the drift rate is sampled from a distribution with mean ν rad and on others the mean is −ν rad . There was a general preference across experiments and participants for models with bimodal distributions of drift rate. As we remarked earlier, this kind of bimodality suggests that drift rates depend on the outputs of a perceptually opponent-process motion system. Adelson and Bergen (1985) argued that motion mechanisms are perceptually opponent in precisely this way. They pointed out that it is generally not possible to see leftward and rightward motion in the same place within the same frequency band. In the case of grating stimuli, for example, a pair of sine wave gratings traveling in opposite directions are perceived as flickering in counterphase, suggesting the motion signals cancel each other out. They argued that a plausible general model for motion perception is one in which quadrature-pair filters sensitive to opposite direction of motion are wired together in opponency. When the outputs of these kinds of filters are noise-perturbed, as occurs in the RDM task, for example, the most strongly responding member of such an opponent pair will determine the percept of motion. Our modeling results, which favor models with bimodal distributions of drift rates, are consistent with this kind of opponency. Potentially, then, the shadow mode in continuous outcome RDM decisions may reflect either trial-to-trial variability in the strengths of the responses in the individual components of quadrature pair filters or differences in the outputs of members of mutually-inhibitory quadrature pairs acting in opponency. Consistent with this observation, Bae and Luck (2022) reported a simulation study using an implementation of a motion energy model by Kiani et al. (2008) which those authors used to represent neural activity in area MT. Bae and Luck put their stimuli through the model and found the outputs agreed with the empirical data: The highest output was in the true motion direction; the next highest output was in the antipodal direction, and the lowest output was in the orthogonal direction. These results are consistent with the idea that a motion-energy mechanism determines the drift rate in a diffusion decision process.

div.head: Other kinds of bimodality
div.p: We have considered bimodality in continuous-outcome decisions in the specific and restricted context of the RDM task. However, the issue of bimodality in continuous-outcome decisions is more general than this. It was first raised by Ratcliff (2018) in relation to a comparative-brightness task requiring decisions about which of several Gaussian luminance blobs in an array of random pixel noise was brightest. Ratcliff argued that the SCDM, which involves a race among an infinite array of accumulators, provides a natural way to represent decisions of this kind. While we agree that the SCDM provides a plausible way to model these kinds of decisions, we do not believe they require a race model to explain them as a matter of necessity, any more than do the diverse variety of two-choice decision tasks that have been studied in the cognitive literature. Many two-choice decisions involve a comparison of two stimuli that are both present in a display: Which of two stimuli is the target, or which of them is longer, brighter, or more numerous? Race models, like the leaky competing accumulator model, the dual diffusion model, and other similar models conceive of the decision process in these tasks as a race between separate evidence totals, each representing a response. In contrast, in the standard diffusion model, the evidence entering the decision process is the result of a comparison of the alternatives made prior to evidence accumulation, with the sign of the result determining the direction in which evidence accumulates. Whether there is a single stimulus in the display and the alternatives being compared are cognitive representations in the decision maker's head or the alternatives are both physically present in the display is immaterial to the logical and mathematical structure of the model. We think exactly the same considerations apply in relation to continuous outcome tasks. Ratcliff (2018) suggested that the drift rate for the circular diffusion model in the comparative brightness task may depend on the vector sum, or average, of the drift rates for the competing stimuli. If so, then the model would predict unimodal distributions of decision outcomes centered on a point somewhere between the two alternatives. However, these predictions rely tacitly on the assumption that the processes that compute drift rates are linear: Even when the decision maker is trying to pick the strongest of two stimuli the linearity of the process will lead to compulsory averaging, resulting in a drift-rate vector that lies between them. In contrast, our theoretical inclination is to view the processes that compute drift rates as inherently nonlinear -plausibly, as following a MAX, or maximum-of-outputs, rule (e.g. Eckstein et al., 2000) in which the response depends on the largest or the strongest of a set of competing alternatives. MAX-rule dynamics arise naturally in competitive interaction neural architectures, like the competitive interaction model of attention and decision-making of Smith and Sewell (2013) and the related neural model of Cox et al. (2022), in which the excitation or activation in one process inhibits all of the other processes in its neighborhood. When these kinds of competitive interactions are controlled by nonlinear dynamics like those analyzed by Grossberg and colleagues (Grossberg, 1980), then MAX-rule behavior occurs: The most strongly activated unit saturates and the activity of its competitors is suppressed. We think of drift rates in tasks like the comparative brightness task as being governed by these kinds of competitive interaction dynamics. Compulsory averaging is not a feature of systems of this kind and they would not predict drift rates that lie between the alternatives. The two-component drift-rate distribution that we have used to fit our RDM data would most naturally be viewed as arising from winner-take-all competitive interaction dynamics implemented at the neural level. These kinds of nonlinear dynamics are needed theoretically to obtain a single vector-valued drift rate from a population of units that individually signal evidence for a continuous range of response alternatives. In contrast, Ratcliff's SCDM is linear up until the point of response.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this article, we have developed the spherical diffusion model as a model for continuousoutcome RDM tasks and compared it to versions of the circular diffusion model, with and without an antipodal component of drift rate. Mathematically, the spherical diffusion model belongs to the same class of models as the circular and hyperspherical diffusion models and can be analyzed using the same methods that are used to analyze them. In the RDM task, the additional dimension of evidence accumulation in the spherical model can be related theoretically to the decision-maker's uncertainty about the identity of the encoded stimulus. As the elevation of the drift-rate vector increases, the predicted distribution of decision outcomes becomes less concentrated and, in the limit, when the drift-rate vector is perpendicular to the response plane, it is uniformly distributed around the response circle.

We showed that a version of the spherical model with an antipodal component of drift rate successfully predicted distributions of decision outcomes in the RDM task, including the bimodal distributions found for some participants, and accounted for the shapes of the joint distributions of decision outcomes and RT, as represented by Q × Q plots. When augmented with a drift-rate bias model, which assumes that drift rates vary with the polar angle of the motion stimulus, the model successfully predicted the biases in the signed angular errors of decision outcomes and RT. The additional flexibility of the spherical model endows it with properties that may be useful in other settings beyond the RDM task.

As discussed previously, the circular diffusion model predicts von Mises distributions of decision outcomes. Many continuous outcome tasks in the VWM literature and other areas produce peaked, heavy-tailed distributions that can be modeled as mixtures of von Mises and uniform distributions. The von Mises component characterizes the peaked central portion of the distribution and the uniform component characterizes its tails. A uniform distribution can be viewed as a von Mises distribution with zero precision, so such models can equivalently be viewed as mixtures of von Mises components with high and low

figure.head: Figure 5 :
figure.figDesc: Drift-rate bias model. (a) A stimulus presented at location θ is represented by a drift rate vector, ν, with a component ν in the response plane. Drift-rate bias is represented by a set of bias vectors, b i , in the response plane. (b) The resultant component of drift rate is the vector sum of the drift rate associated with the stimulus and the nearest bias vector. (c) The drift-rate biases are exponentially decaying functions of the distance between the stimulus at θ and the bias vector at ϕ in the 1 − cos(•) circular distance metric. The total bias is the sum of the biases associated with each of the bias vectors.

chose a model with four bias vectors after inspection of the individual participants' distributions of responses and based on our prior experience in fitting models with different numbers of bias vectors to the data of Smith et al. (2020). A more detailed characterization of bias would have allowed both the amplitudes of the individual bias vectors and the number of vectors for each participant to vary, as was done by Smith et al., but this would have enlarged our model space unduly. The four-component model captures many of the regularities in our data, as we show subsequently.

The points on the x-axis in these plots are nine equally-spaced quantiles of the distributions of decision outcomes and the points on the y-axis are the .1, .3, .5, .7, and .9 quantiles of the distributions of RT.Figure 8shows the predictions of the drift-bias model as a function of the polar angle of the stimulus: The left-hand panels show the mean signed angular error of the responses; the right-hand panels show the median RT. The distributions of decision outcomes for all participants inFigure 6have secondary modes like those in the data ofBae and Luck (2019) inFigure 1. Participants MP1 through MP3 all show large secondary modes; MP4 shows a much smaller mode. The remaining participant (MP5) had a similar pattern of data to MP4, with a small secondary mode.

figure.figDesc: component models -which had an antipodal drift-rate component -performed better than the single-component models. All models could successfully predict the distributions of decision outcomes, including the secondary modes, and the marginal distributions of RT without difficulty. The main challenge for the models, and the principal constraint on them, was also to predict the joint distributions of outcomes and RTs. As discussed previously in relation inFigure 3, all four models tend to predict double-bowed Q×Q functions, to a greater or lesser extent, although, as shown inFigures 7 and 9, the spherical models can also predict a simpler, dished, slow-error pattern in some parts of the parameter space,similar to that predicted by the single-component circular diffusion model with drift-rate variability. Many of the individual Q × Q plots in Figure 7 show evidence of the doublebowed pattern, although the most diagnostic parts of the distribution for identifying these effects are in the tail quantiles of the RT distributions at intermediate decision outcomes, where the data are sparsest, so the effects are unavoidably noisy. The main point of differentiation between the four models is in the magnitude of the double-bow or slow-error pattern they predict. double-bow patterns than spherical models. Single-component models predict large doublebow patterns because their only mechanism for predicting the secondary mode is through variability in the radial component of drift rate, η rad . In order to predict the large secondary modes inFigure 6, η rad must be large, which results in a large slow-error pattern. If there is variability in the radial component of drift rate but not in the tangential component, then a double-bow pattern results. Even when the model has an antipodal component of drift rate, as was the case of the model CIRC(−ν, η), the double-bow pattern typically exceeded that found in the data.In comparison, the spherical diffusion models fared better, because the elevation of the drift-rate vector above the equatorial plane, represented by the parameter φ, gives them an additional degree of freedom. As discussed previously in relation toFigure 3, the center of the distribution of hitting points increases as φ increases and, in the limit, when φ = π/2, the distribution is centered on the north pole. When the hitting points of this distribution are projected down the meridians of equal azimuth to the response circle, a uniform distribution of decision outcomes results. Software was written in PsychToolbox. The stimuli consisted of moving 10 × 10 pixel white dots, presented within a circular aperture of 4 deg radius, surrounded by a narrow (one pixel wide) 5 deg radius response circle. The dots were generated within an 8 × 8 deg square patch centered on
figure.note: , in which each dot is presented for three frames (∼ 35 ms) and then replotted at a new location and the coherence of the motion is determined probabilistically for each dot each time it is replotted. To avoid global perceptual transients when dots are replotted the lifetimes of the individual dots are uncorrelated with each other. The probability that a dot moved coherently was 0.30 in all four exposure duration conditions. There were a total of 50 dots presented within a 5 degree circular aperture and dots that exited the aperture were replotted at random locations at the beginning of the next lifetime to keep the mean dot density constant. Stimuli in Experiment 2 were presented on a 20"2 The ViSage framestore has two modes: native ViSaGe mode and BITS# mode. In native mode the ViSaGe runs asynchronously from the host computer and all aspects of stimulus timing and response recording are handled by the ViSaGe's onboard clock. In BITS# mode, display timing and response recording are handled by the host computer. Experiment 1 was run in BITS# mode because it allows responses to be made using a mouse.
